=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Bang is an average game, and when compared to similar bluffing games like The Resistance or Werewolf, it just doesn't stand up. The game takes too long, has unbalanced roles, tries to be strategic and bluff-based simultaneously and tends to fail on both fronts, as the cards can create a luck based game. Although the strategy is certainly there, and mitigates some luck, it is an inherently a highly imperfect game that tends to languish in my collection.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Still one of my favorite social shoot out strategy games.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Party card game that is essentially a "take that!" game, with a very strong theme, an excellent bluffing aspect, and role selection/variable character powers.

This game is going to work very well for beginners and/or large groups (scales from 3-8 with expansions, which I strongly recommend, particularly "Dodge City"), keeping in mind that it's almost non-existent strategy, but rather quick, fun, and very replayable filler material.

One negative is that players are often and easily killed off early, and this leaves them with literally nothing to do until the game ends, which although is generally quick, can occasionally drag.

On the plus side, aside from the replayability due to variety in changing characters and roles, this game has both competitive and co-operative elements to it (the outlaws can win together, the deputies can win with the sheriff), and a nice bluffing element to it, which is where most of the strategy lies.  I've heard complaints about the Renegade never winning, and yet some of my best games have been when I've bluffed my way through the entire game as a deputy only to turn around and kill the sheriff and, sometimes his real deputy, at the end of the game- surprise!  Worth the small amount of money it's going to cost you to buy.

Own the [boardgame=9653]Dodge City[/boardgame], [boardgame=66508]Wild West[/boardgame], [boardgame=107794]Gold Rush[/boardgame], [boardgame=130046]Valley of Shadows[/boardgame], [boardgame=8269]High Noon[/boardgame], and [boardgame=20237]Fistful of Cards[/boardgame] expansions, and the [boardgame=217972]Bloody Mary[/boardgame] promo card.  Dodge City, Wild West and Gold Rush are must haves, the other two don't get much use, but have the potential to spice up the base game in the future.

RATING: 8
I finally got to play this game at The Cast are Dice and had an absolute blast!  It did help that I won - as the Sheriff - and what's more no-one took a single shot at me, despite the fact that the game lasted 40 mins and everyone was shooting everyone else.
Mind you, I did have a really good character to go with the role, and the fact that no-one shot at me made it really hard to spot who wasn't the Deputy, which was a balancing factor.

The game plays out EXACTLY like I thought that it would from reading the rules - and I wasn't the least bit disapponted.  I had a lot of fun and that was what I expected.  It is a great game to play in a group of 6 or 7 and perfect for getting out with the right crowd at Christmas.  The only problem is that you can be eliminated early on and that can be a drag...but you gotta love this game anyway!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
Different roles determines the different objectives to win the game. Sheriff must eliminate all outlaws and renegades. Deputy helps the sheriff with his mission. The outlaws tries to kill the sheriff. And the renegade must kill everyone else except the sheriff and be the last one standing between the him and the sheriff.

With different characters to choose from, there'll be different special abilities. Shoot by playing the 'Bang' card and to not be hit, play the 'Mancato' card. Drink beer to replenish life.

Awesome game! Anything can happens. Sheriff may kill his deputy, therefore losing everything he has. Outlaw may kill his member just to get bonus cards.

Love being the renegade...

RATING: 7
A fun card game.  What could be better than reenacting wild west fights between deputies and outlaws with cards?  Half the fun is not knowing who has which role (except for the Sherriff, who is declared).  I like this one, though I think some of the win conditions (which are role-based) are a little bit tough.  Last man standing vs. kill all the bad guys vs. don't let the Sheriff die?  In my opinion, better with more people though also a bit more confusing and crazy (which is, of course, more fun!).

Rating lowered from 8 to 7.  A good game, but not one I look to play.  The game mechanics leave me feeling like gameplay is random and hard to control.  For me, there is less emphasis on figuring out other people's roles and achieving your goal than just doing things to see what happens.

RATING: 9
Amazingly fun and addictive.  An excellent light game to play after something heavy, or to start out the evening.

It has been described, by people in my group, as "Werewolf with Strategy" or as "Lunch Money with structure".  It feels to me like a mx of those games, taking the best of each and combining them.  My only small quibble is that the outlaws have a significant advantage, and win much more than the sherrif team.  This is much less so in a game with an odd number of players....I recommend playing with 5 players, as that is the best number.  7 is pretty good but too long, and too long between turns.  Below 5, it is less interesting.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
Owned by Nathan
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.7
Players can take up different roles: Sherif, Deputy, Outlaw and Renegade.  Only the identity of the Sherif is exposed while the rest secretly helps or plots against the sherif.

The deputies are to help the sherif to kill all the outlaws, outlaws' goal are to kill the sherif.  The renegade aims to kill all the rest of the players.

All players by default can only shoot the person beside them till they get better guns or weapons.  There are other cards like the beer to refill the hearts of a character, general store and many more others.

Good points: This is a semi-cooperative games which players of the same interest cooperate with each other.  Game is fun with a rowdy group of players.

Bad points: When 1 player dies without the game ending, he cannot be revived.  Player will have to wait for the game to end before starting another round.  During this time the player might be bored as he is not participating in the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Lots of fun to play with the right group. Plays best with 5 or 7 players. The downside it is a player elimination game but this is glossed over by the quick play (20 - 30 minutes). The major drawback of the game is that more often than not it takes a few turns to figure out who some of the players are. But during that time it's not uncommon for one or more players to be killed. In fact, it's possible to die in this game before you even take a turn. Occasionally it will take a new player a little while to figure out just what is really going on (figuring out which role each player has) but it's still fun. Player who over analyze will really slow this game down. Bang is best played as a fast, lite game. Luckily Shadow Hunters is almost the same game but adds a way to help you figure out who is who.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Excellent implementation of the Spaghetti Western feeling in a party/deduction game with player elimination. I prefer it to Night Hunters for example (which is another popular of the genre) due to the fact that it can be a lot more strategic and love the theme of the Wild West. The downtime is that it might drag a bit sometimes or people might get eliminated too early but that's due to the nature of gunfighting. After all it's funny even to be on the table talking with the others. It surely depends on your playing companions. It get's better with Dodge City and we play with the tournament rules for scoring and always with Spaghetti Western music in the backgroung when playing!

RATING: 4.5
Low quality production that caused a lot of confusion. (And you only want to play this with a big group.)

The dice game improved the experience by cleaning up the rules and removing choice. (Not that this makes it a good game, but at least it goes faster.)

RATING: 7

The game can drag out really long if everyone plays passive or gets unlucky with cards draws. Player elimination is a huge problem when the game drags out. It's also incredibly hard to teach because there are so many symbols and so many things going on.

RATING: 2

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Half the people in my group hate Bang, the other half loves it.  The truth is that it's decent fun and works pretty well for large groups.  In smaller groups it plays pretty quickly.  

Its biggest problem comes from the fact that it does have player elimination, and it's totally possible to be killed of and out of the game before your turn even comes around.

If you survive long enough squeeze off a few rounds, and throw down a high-noon duel or two you'll probably enjoy yourself.  On top of that, liberal use of the term "bang" is guaranteed to bring out the giggles in all but the stuffiest and overly mature groups.

update:
the last few times I've played this it has drawn out way too long.  While it's true that my group does tend to play things slowly, I think I'd have to be convinced to play this one again anytime soon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
very light.  has been fun in many cases, particularly when the players do their best to obscure their roles.  in other cases, a card game with few choices (because you either know who your friends and opponents are or you only know who the sheriff is).  I pity the sheriff who gets to sit there, bored.  I also pity the Renegade who has such a low chance of winning.  In fact, I pity the Deputies too, who don't want to shoot each other or the renegade.  The Outlaws are the hinge of the game.  Once they start shooting AT THE SHERIFF, the game can be fun.  Unless it locks down again (due to lack of bullets, no guns, etc) which often happens.  Additionally, I feel the characters are significantly unbalanced.  Finally, just too long for the small amount of fun.  I'm not a big fan of games based on psychology (e.g., Diplomacy), but this one seems especially poor unless you're playing with some very extroverted people.  I used to like the game a lot, but each play I find myself enjoying it less.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Bluff, intimidation et vengence, ce jeu est vraiment excellent lorsque l'on veut defouler son surplus de testosterone... Un poker avec une ambiance western, un de mes classique, mais a 6 et +

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Like so many multi-player card games, this one took a while for some of our group (ie, the wives) to warm up to. However, once you get the basic language down, and can know what a special card does without having to refer back to the Horribly designed rule book, the game becomes quite enjoyable. I like that this game really has two levels: one is the basic do damage to your opponents to win, but another level is much like Werewolf, where you can never really be sure who is friend or foe (or both). This second dynamic becomes much more pronounced and important proportionate to the number of times each player has played this game. Bluffing, "accidental" misplays, and other actions make this second aspect of Bang better, and therefore makes the game rate higher than the typical group card game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Also game play is too chaotic to my taste. I also don't like the player elimination much.

RATING: 6.5
I have now played a handful of games with 5, 6 and 7 players.  One of the reasons I was attracted to German Games was the fact that player elimination was not a requirement of games.  That is the main goal of this one and I still thoroughly enjoy it.  

Of our games, I enjoyed playing with six most, but they have been due to using the seven players to teach FOUR new players!   I have found one thing difficult regarding this game and it's people who are unfamiliar with the cards knowing what to do in certain situations and that creates a lot of time having people reread the rules to get things straight.  It's put me off the game with each extra play. 

Each game is different as your own personal goals and abilities change with different roles and personalities.  A very good game when played with people who don't mind laughing at themselves!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A light game with a favorite theme, the Wild West, that I always enjoy. It's great that you can play with 8  people, and the rules are fairly simple. Hidden agendas of each player means everyone has fun trying to figure out who is who. Thus this game has card playing skill factor, and a psychological element. 

I love games that pack a lot of strategy and fun in a small package. Bang! is of this type. Recommended as a party game and for card floppers, but of course can also be played in a competitive fashion.

RATING: 8

I also feel that our group is so used to games where the players aren't eliminated, they grate at getting knocked out and having to sit idly by watching the rest of us interact.  Usually the time is minimal, but like I said, they've been spoiled with so many non-elimination games.  I'll have to lobby hard to get more games of Bang! in.  [Market price]

RATING: 7.5
Great game though it require it's players. While 3 is the minimum, or perhaps 4, you need atleast 5 to make things really interesting. This game is a given each time we get 5 or more people together for a night of fun.
Good humor and originality. Very good gameplay with lots of people and very very easy to learn. A game of deception and intriguing more then anything where the goal is to kill the sheriff.. or in the case of you happening to be him kill everyone else.
Comes with a number of fun characters with different traits which are randomly selected each game. Each are good in their own way and keep it interesting even after many games played. A great tip for this game is to get the expansions dodge city and high noon.

RATING: N/A

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
Lachi
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Bang! can be an accessible, fun game well-suited for social gatherings and non-gamers.  On the other hand, it can be a bit hard to understand the rules, and for its hidden roles, it isn't all that mysterious (Saboteur does a much better job at that).  Overall, it's still good fun, and is best in social situations where you can play the game and do other things at the same time, and when played fairly quickly.

After many plays, I prefer to play with the base game (minus 1-3 beers), the Dodge City characters and non-green cards, and a house rule that each player can only have two blue cards at any given time (excluding Jail and Dynamite). I will also usually throw in (most of) A Fistful of Cards if everyone is willing, but don't mind playing without it. The result is shorter games with less defense, which I greatly prefer to the long standoffs that can occur without these tweaks. 

Rating based on playing at a fairly quick pace. If playing slowly: -> 4. (2008-10)

After a number of additional plays, many with new players but some with people who already know how to play, I have to downgrade Bang!'s rating. There is virtually no element of mystery except for the Renegade/Vice distinction, and thus very few meaningful decisions to make in the game. Even with experienced players, I quickly become bored unless we are playing at breakneck speed. The game is simply too much time waiting for my next turn, or playing more or less automatically out-of-turn. While I still enjoy the characters and some of the mechanisms on a conceptual level, the game as a whole simply doesn't hold up, and is always more fun in my mind than it actually is. Not a good sign. 7 -> 4. (2014-10)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
p: Avoid playing it with people who cannot hack elimination games, especially if they draw the short straw. If people don't mind the possibility of an early exit than they might discover an atmospheric, pleasant, albeit lengthy filler.

Combining a who-dunnit element with an all-out shoot-fest makes for intriguing play and the introduction of range, objects and variable abilities into a strong theme certainly brings it alive and increases its replay value. But when you are dealing with a game from which players can be eliminated even before they had a single turn, that more than suggests it's not the type of game to get too analytical about. And who not to play it with. 
  
On the whole I don't enjoy it when players have to step out early, and those games are rated as such. So apart from playing it in situations when drop-outs can quickly move on to something else (conventions anyone?), I cannot see myself suggesting it often. Nevertheless, with the right people and in the right mood it certainly can be enjoyable, especially if you manage to survive the initial kills. I would like to like it better than I do, I guess, which says something for its fun-potential too.

For a quick no barrels hold all-out shoot-fest it is bang on. For serious gamers who crave for control over other player's actions through sound strategy, first play will also have been its last chance saloon.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
I'll admit that BANG! was the game that got me into the board game hobby. The social interaction and deduction was ever present, and it was fun to "bang" out combinations with your cards.

However, after having played over 20 times with a varied number of players, the flaws of the game have grown on me to the point where I would like to sell or trade my copy of the game.

My biggest complaint is that the game is too long to be a filler and not meaty enough to be worthy of the average 1h+ playing time. The game draws on too long with players recuperating health at the same rate as they are taking damage.

Otherwise, I guess BANG! is a good gateway game if you would like to try your hand at something deeper and more rewarding than traditional board games; however, it might not stay in your collection for very long as you branch out into better games.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
My favorite games usually have either secrets or treasure, or, if I'm lucky, secret treasure. The enjoyment I draw from this game is the excitement of not knowing what characters my friends are playing.  I've played it 4 or 5 times, and I like it for a quick group game.  It's not my favorite card game or my favorite party game, but I'd like to try out an expansion.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
The absolute best type of filler; plays quickly, fun mechanics, and filled to the brim with flavour.  Play it with the soundtrack to "The Good, The Bad, and The Ugly" playing in the background for the ultimate Old West experience.  This just brings the fun, and afterwards, you'll be talking about all those cool gaming stories for days, like the time that "Bart" and "Lucky Dan" killed the sheriff before she got a second turn, or that time the sheriff blew himself up with the dynamite on turn two, or maybe the story where he refused to believe in his deputy, right up to the very, very end, or ... well, you get the point.  Meant as filler, but sometimes it hits the table and nobody wants to stop playing.  Grab a deck and invent your own "legends" of the west.  (as a side note, people who complain about balance issues in this game really don't have a clue what it's all about)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When you play Bang! you can’t have enough of it: its light-hearted, quick-paced, full-fun theme screams for «just another run».

The expansions - though introducing new items, characters and cards - add very little to the basic game, which plays very good by itself: the only one I could recommend is «Dodge City», for it raises the number of players to eight.

I’m also curious about the forthcoming «Gold Rush» expansion, only because of the Bud Spencer and Therence Hill-inspired characters, a mandatory tribute to the genre. (September 2011)

Edit: After massively playing it over the last months, Bang! scaled down to a decent filler lasting too long: nonetheless, it can be moderately fun when newcomers and non-gamers are around, since it’s probably a game like none they played before, yet it still lacks any real appeal to the more seasoned gamers, who instead are prone to shoot the first one who dares say «just another run».

As a consequence, rating lowered from 7.5 to 6.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
If I lived back in the wild west days, instead of carrying a six-gun in my holster, I'd carry a soldering iron. That way, if some smart-aleck cowboy said something like "Hey, look. He's carrying a soldering iron!" and started laughing, and everybody else started laughing, I could just say, "That's right, it's a soldering iron. The soldering iron of justice." Then everybody would get real quiet and ashamed, because they had made fun of the soldering iron of justice, and I could probably hit them up for a free drink.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Volt szerencsém akkor játszani ezt a játékot, mikor még csak külföldről lehetett beszerezni. Megtanultuk az összes kártyát, betéve tudtuk. Hatalmas, emlékezetes partikat játszottunk, de mára a számtalan társasjáték háttérbe szorította. Szerintem nem gond a kiesés, mert a kiesők is végig figyelték a játékot. Azért egy idő után mikor végtelenségbe futott a játék, időlimittel abbahagytuk és jöhetett az új parti. Az egyik alkalommal egy barátomnál az ötéves kislány (3 nagyobb testvére van) rángatta a szülőket, hogy játszanak egy Bang-et. Na gondoltam ez is valami vicc lesz, hogy csak a kártyák dobálgatása miatt szórakozik a játékkal. Legnagyobb megdöbbenésemre, együl játszotta végig a partit, és  minden kártyát tudta mire való. Úgy csente el a többiektől pánik lappal a megfelelő kártyát, hogy csak lestem. Na itt kész voltam és újra kell gondolnom egy ilyen játék hány éves kortól játszható. Lehet, hogy legközelebb egy Terra Mystica-t fogok vinni a hónam alatt és megtanitom neki :D
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
111 pieces
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Good game for 5-7 players. A few years ago I would have rated this even higher, but I've played it so much that I'm a bit burnt out by now. Easiest way to teach the game is to first introduce the roles and their different objectives, and then teach players how to read the symbols on the cards. 
If your group is looking for a Werewolf with more meat on it, Bang! is a good idea.

RATING: 6

I feel like you need to play this game with 7 players so there are 2 deputies and more uncertainties for everyone.  When it comes to bluffing about hidden alliance cards, I prefer the Shadows over Camelot game which gives players more control over their actions... and certainly, actions speak loader than words in Bang! and Shadows.

Home rules:
為了增加警長的生存力，以及彌補最後才能行動玩家的不利，提供這些玩家一些選擇強力角色的機會。
假設遊玩人數為N，先在角色堆中隨機抽出N+1張角色，然後再隨機抽出３張，由警長先進行選擇，補充一張後以逆時計方向（即最後行動的玩家）傳給下一位玩家，如此類推直到所有玩家選擇角色完畢。所以第一個行動的玩家只能在最後２張職業中選擇其中一張。同時也避免了警長旁邊出現２隻過強角色的問題。

RATING: 8
Great game. I haven't used any of the expansions yet, but the base game has been a hit with my group. Best with 7, but good enough with 5.

Update 6/14/09: Played with the Dodge City expansion. We actually had 8 players so the timing was good. I like the extra characters. I also like having more cards. The jury is still out on the green bordered cards. The main advantage seems to be getting in another shot without using a Bang! card. I'm not sure if it's worth the extra confusion of having cards with similar purposes that have a different name. We'll see.

RATING: N/A
Emiliano Sciarra
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
This one had me a little puzzled when I played it. You're all given a secret role, which reminded me of Citadels a bit. Except the sheriff who is publically known to be the sheriff. But his two deputies, 3 outloaws and one renegade are all secret identies. Now there's a very clever ranging mechanism, in that your seating arrangement is relevant, youc an only shoot so far to your left or right depending upon the range of your weapon. That much is sweet. But combine that with the fact that as a deptuy you're on the sheriffs side and as an outlaw you're not, and no-one likes being accidentally shot by their mates, it only takes one or two practice games before everyone sees the vested interest in announcing unambiguously who's side their on. I mean why shoot randomly at people and get shot at randomly? Even before you work that out, the first person to shoot the sherif is either an outlaw or a stupid depty who wants to draw fire from the sheriff and the other deputy, and so it all falls into place in a matter of minytes who is who. Except for the renegade who'd like to remain secret, but what chance has he given that everyone else has a vested interest in publicising their identity. Worse yet, as a deputy the game seems completly mindless as you're job is to protect the sheriff but there is nothing at all you can do to achieve this except not shoot him. A totally frustrating impotence as deputy when you'd like to be able to lend the sheriff a hand somehow if times are tough beyond just taking pot shots at outlaws. And the poor as the poor old renegade no-one is on your side, everyone knows who you are right away as mentioned above and the only thing going for you is that the outloaws and good guys are actually more interested in wiping one anothe rout than you, so all you can do is take pot shots at the winning side now and then to keep the balance and try and win yourslef (which you can only do if you're the last one alive!). In short, as renegade the game also sucks somewhat in that you have nothing really interesting to do exzcept act as balance keeper for the other two sides and hope for the best (as six guns turn on you if you get to bothersome).

So while the game certinnly captures ome neat mechanics, ideas and thematics, somehow it falls flat for me in delivering fun and entertainment just taking pot shots at people and not really having a whole olot of planning, strategy or tactics to challenge you with. 

I'd call it a light hearted filler game to play between games or at the start or end of a games night. And yet for that it seems it can drag on a bit long sometimes alas ...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Also, it sucks being eliminated early and having to watch everyone else play.

RATING: 6
We had a ton of fun with this game when we were a group of 5 casual players on a train. In our larger group of regulars however it didn't work out so well.

There's a sweet spot of 5 or 6 players for this game. With less the roles aren't as interesting and with more it takes too long and it's too random - with large number of players it's not unlikely to be eliminated before you even get a turn or two.

[microbadge=24903][microbadge=29024]

RATING: 1
Oh my, do I dislike this game.  Why is it everyone carries this stupid card game around and then pulls it out in large groups?

It's so boring.  It's even more boring when everyone instantly kills you because you bitch about the game and you end up having to watch other people play the stupid game and watch it drag on.  

 I think that common perception that non-gamers should play this game is false.  I think new players should be introduced to the best games, not the most mediocre!  Remember, "non-gamers" aren't necessarily idiots requiring simplicity -- they're just inexperienced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
In this game, three sides battle for victory: the sheriff and deputies, the oultaws, and the renegade.  Only the sheriff's identity is known, and all the other roles are hidden.  The sheriff and deputies have to kill off all the outlaws and the renegade to win, while the outlaws only have to kill the sheriff, and the renegade wins if he is the last man standing.  This game is best if you play with seven players (the maximum). 

However, this game becomes very repetitive once you discover that if you are an outlaw, your best strategy is to always shoot the sheriff when possible.  Then everyone's roles become quickly discernible and the game quickly degenerates into who can defend or kill the sheriff.

RATING: 1
Sucks like a souped-up hoover. Game seems like it lasts only as long as it takes the oulaws to kill the Sheriff, usually about twice around the table. No other role has any hope of winning, least of all the hopeless Renegade who is doomed to lose and have virtually no impact on the game. If the appalling play-balance problems weren't enough, the game is additionally almost completely uninteresting, with nothing in the way of choices that aren't utterly obvious. Avoid like the plague. I've heard this compared to Werewolf, which I think is a completely inappropriate comparison (as much as I didn't care for Werewolf, this is much, much worse). I have to admit I am utterly amazed by this game's high average rating; usually (like in Carcassone or Citadelles) I can just chuckle and ascribe it to taste, but this game is so utterly awful, I simply have no conception of where these ratings came from. Maybe a candidate for that list ...

RATING: 8
Bang! has captured that one elusive quality that all board games strive to achieve-- "playability."  While that may not even be a real word, gamers know what it means.  No one ever has any objections to pulling Bang! out of the box.  There may not be many opportunities to derive a strategic decision from this chaos-turned-card-game, but it's too fun not to try.  For example, the Renegade is seldom victorious, but I want to play him the most just for the challenge.  At such a low price, this game deserves its popularity.

RATING: 8
After a few initial plays, I like the game, but it's not a favorite so far.  I love waiting to see which role and character I'll draw and after that, it becomes an experiment to see who can draw the best combinations of cards.  Oh, you're the outlaw sitting next to the sherrif and have happened to draw a volcanic and seven bang cards?  That was fun.  Let's redeal...

On the plus side, it's easy to get people to play it because it's a light little affair without too much thought or a big learning curve. 

UPDATE: It's been years now that I've owned this game and we still bust it out and have a great time with it.  There's too much atmosphere to not love the game and it fills a special role within my collection.  It's not perfect, but it's dang fun if you don't play it too much.

RATING: 5
Overall, I'm just not a huge fan of games with a bunch of "take that!" card play, and that's most of what Bang is about.  At the beginning, you're dealt a secret role, which dictates which players at the table you'll be aiming for.  Then, you all start killing each other via card play!

While the game is still ok for me, I'm not a big fan of this one without the High Noon expansion which adds a lot of fun and flavor, adding a special event to each round that influences play in different and unexpected ways.  Playing with only the base game leaves me pretty flat, though.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 2
This game, which at it's heart seems to be a hidden team game long outstays it's welcome considering it has player elimination with mechanics that focus on two things dealing damage to someone and avoiding damage slash healing damage.

Someone gets beat down. They get back up. And so it goes until someone is unlucky. and they get eliminated. Then they can sit back and watch the same pattern repeat itself for all of the other players.

Wow.

As for the hidden roles, they aren't all that hidden. The outlaws attack the sheriff, the deputies and the sheriff attack the outlaws, and the renegade pretends to be a deputy until all the deputies and outlaws are dead. It's clever, but it means the roles aren't actually hidden (except, arguably, the renegade's).

I should point out that the role natives play in the game, as people who show up and try to kill all the whiteys, is, if I'm feeling generous, culturally insensitive, and if I'm not, simply racist.

The dice game version is far superior to the original card game version.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

I seem to recall sort of enjoying this with non-gamers, but it's been so long that I can't remember, and now that it's traded I doubt I'll ever play it again.

RATING: 7
Donated to Kinkora Regional High School Board Game Club that I started in February 2011

Received as part of Math trade with Dodge City for Ingenious Challenges and Small world Tales and Legends
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
When I was new to games, I LOVED Bang! Now I'm pretty over it.

Bang! does one thing exceedingly well that no other game does: the theme is actually immersive. There's a fun roleplay aspect where you really feel like you're in the wild west gunning each other down. This is due to a few things: (1) the fact that the sheriff is revealed (2) the distance seating system (3) the lack of board. Everything is just your equipment and actions and (4) the variable powers (5) the PLAYER ELIMINATION. An unpopular thing to say, but I think that it's one of the things that makes the game work.

While it adds to the theme, the player elimination is a real problem as people can be eliminated before they even get a turn. This issue is exacerbated by the game's length, which is a problem all its own. At this point in my gaming life, if I'm going to play something this silly and chaotic I want it done in WELL under an hour, ESPECIALLY if there's elimination!

Quick note on the variable player powers. This is a mechanic I love and I am convinced that to date, no game has done them as well as  Bang! They all change the way that each game goes down for EVERYONE while staying reasonably balanced (now that they fixed the blue guy...) And they're all interesting. I think this even beats out Cosmic Encounter, where it seems every game someone has a power that's just lame.

The scaling is basically nonexistent as well. Play with four? More like snore! Play with 7+? Sure, if you want the game to run 2 hours. Ugh.

The hidden roles are also almost meaningless. Generally it takes a bit to figure out which is the renegade vs. the deputy but that's completely irrelevant unless you're Sheriff. But honestly, that's not that big of an issue.

In my experience, casual/nongamers are always fascinated by the concept and want to try it. It definitely gets points for that! Just beware though that there's a lot of small, fiddly rules to remember that can make it a hassle to teach new players.

All in all I'd recommend to someone new to the hobby but it's not something I suggest anymore.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I was able to buy a cheap copy, but with The Resistance, Cash n Guns, Saboteur, Shadow Hunters and many other games like Bang on my shelves, I just didn't see an opportunity to get it played. I would like to play it one day, but it seems like it's too long compared to many other "hidden role" games.

Now I finally got to play it. I played this right after playing Bang: The Dice Game, and I must say that the latter is a big improvement! Regular Bang felt way too long and too boring. B:TDG is a good game because it is so short; Bang is not… The alliances and secret teams don’t really work in Bang as it’s clear who is who, and then it’s all about getting the good cards and hurt your enemies (as you should, of course, but the game fell flat after B:TDG). Also, the renegade must be one of the most imbalanced cards in any game – even if the other players played crappy, it should be impossible to win with that character (yes, I know that many of you will probably claim that you’ve won playing the renegade, but man is he severely underpowered and I feel like I have already lost the game when drawing him – which just makes the game feel even longer)!

RATING: 6
FUN! I don't know what else to say. It's just grand, stinking fun. I know everyone says the 4-player version isn't as much fun, but I've played dozens and dozens with 4 and it's fine with my group. Even when we know what everybody is we still totally get into it and just enjoy the ride. 

Update 01/09
Sometimes the game is just too damn long and enjoyment is directly tied to who is playing. I was excited to try the game and play with larger crowds, but it didn't deliver for me the way it did when it was just four of us goofying around and learning about the world of Designer Games. Lowered score to a 5 and I am wishing my friends I original learned this with were around.

Still fun, but mostly for the hilarious inneudo the game generates: "First, I'm going to BANG you, then, because of my special ability, I'm going to BANG you. Then, I'm going to duel you and we'll see who can BANG the longest."

Update 01/10
Turns out that reintroducing it to new players has given this game a new life and energy. It didn't hurt that we played with music from spaghetti westerns in the background. There's a great review of Bang about how the game is less than the sum of its excellent parts. From a gaming perspective, I agree. But when people are playing and having fun----it makes me want to play again!

Update 08/11
Shadow Hunters and Resistance have edged out BANG for our play group (drops a point down to 6). BANG still works for non-gamers and family however.

RATING: 6

Can suffer if nobody is willing the start shooting people, but that means sometimes there are random shots. Lots of opportunity to screw your neighbor, but that means setting yourself up as a target. RATING: 5
The fun in this game boils down to trying to figure out what player is what role, the dynamite card, and killing off other players.  I also enjoy the distance mechanic based on the number of players seated between you and your target player.  There is a conundrum here that the more players makes the game more balanced and tense, but the downtime increases and more players get eliminated and have to wait longer for the next game.  The game also gets bogged down in chrome, fiddly rules, and a loss of fun once the player roles are discovered.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I had read reviews of Shadow Hunters describing that game as "it's Bang, but better." So, I was curious to try the "inferior" version. 

I actually like this better than expected. But I agree--I think Shadow Hunters is better. The reason is that these games are supposed to thrive on the secret identities and the discovery of alliances. In Bang (at least our game!), the roles were pretty obvious to deduce, or an unknown role didn't matter. Gameplay focused on getting guns and good cards. In Shadow Hunters, there's more pressure as the game builds--the secret roles seem much more a central aspect of the game.

Still, this wasn't bad, and I'd be willing to try it again to see if my opinion changes.

Update: 2nd play, and my opinion changed--for the worse. It bugs me that a game where roles are supposed to be secret is ironically fairly easy to decipher. This is where Shadow Hunters is the superior game. Player elimination in Bang can also be a bummer, with the end game dragging on a bit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bang! has provided fun "treachery in compact form" between many a larger game.  It's one of those games that I'd not want to play every week but would be willing to play less often as a filler.  The two problems I have with it are the predictability--with certain numbers of players, finding out who's whom is relatively easy, at least until you get to the last couple of players--and the player special abilities.  Some special abilities, especially the 3-health ones, seem a little underpowered, and if you're the Renegade or if your side gets hit with a couple of these, you might have no chance.  And why do I always end up as the sheriff??
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
This game is awesome with 5+ players. Really enjoy it. 
Great "screw-you" game and its fun to try to guess who is who. Only the Sheriff is revealed.. Then there is a hidden Deputy, Outlaws and Renegades.. All firing bullets all over the place.. The Sheriff's job is to survive and take out the outlaws and Renegades.. The Deputy trying to help the Sheriff, but since the cards are hidden Sheriff has no idea at the beginning where the Deputy are.. The Outlaws and The Renegades are also hidden, they try to fool the Sheriff and think they are the Deputy etc etc.. so its a great fun mechanic and with some beers and the right mood its a blast.. Find it hard for the Renegade to survive though, Since they need to take out the outlaws and kill The Sheriff to Win the game.. Sweet game!

update 1: Have started to play Bang on my iphone instead, a great app and still fun, it even has multiplayer online.

Update 2: Just found out there was a Bang The Dice Game. Since i have problem to bring Bang to the table i think this Dice version can be better!?

RATING: 6
This was one of the first games I really got into. However, if you don't have the right number of players, the gameplay significantly suffers, for example the sheriff has a MASSIVE advantage in a 4 player game to the extend that the minimum number of players should probably just be 5. The cowboy theme is awesome and fun, but it can be a little too easy to guess players' roles since the first time you shoot will probably scream to everyone exactly what your goals are, especially if someone decides to turn the game into a liar's match early on. Basically, the game suffers from an extremely awkward play stage at the beginning where everyone is pretending to be the same role.

RATING: 6.72
Main Positives: Very attractive and there's a lot of variety with the character abilities.

Fun Factor: High to Medium
Complexity: Learning the cards can take a while.
Replayability: Yeah... Played with 6 & 7 players... Might want to play it with 4.

Main Frustrations and Caveats:
It's a slow game. Not much flexibility with a few cards like the beer card which you cannot give to anyone and there are lesser bang cards. It would be better if players have a larger hand of cards and that more bang cards are included. I really like the conflict that goes with the game... it's just not enough especially to satisfy the theme. 

The dice game is much better.

RATING: 3
I heard good things about this game just like I heard Talladega Nights was funny. NEVER listen to fools. This game is not god aweful but it is close. I like the theme and feel and was excited to play my first game. After two turns around I was dead and sat around waiting for about 45 minutes for the game to end. Elimination games suck. Well the second game I stayed in till the bitter 90 minute end. I was the sheriff and after about a half hour I couldn't care less what happened as long as it ended soon....no such luck. Elimination, down time and lack of card play options drag this game down.

Overall Score 3, Appearence 4, Components 5, The Box (storage) 4, Rulebook 6, Ease of Play 6, Mechanics 4, Involvment 4, Replayability 5, Uniqueness 5, Luck 8 v Strategy 2 (The higher the number the more it leans that way.)

RATING: 10
This game is fun... while you're still in it.  Unfortunately, it suffers from the ailment of all games where you can get knocked out early: sitting and watching others play.  Luckily, that doesn't last four hours like in Risk... and if people play a little fast and wild, I like it better.  In any case, though, I still have enjoyed every game I've played, though it does wear thin after a while.  

UPDATE:  I updated my rating from a 6 to a 7 given the ridiculous number of times this hits the table.  In moderation, it's still fun, and I'm hard pressed to find a game that can be played in such a short timeframe with so many participants.  

UPDATE:  I upped my rating more.  It's not a heavy game or a deep game, but for me, it approaches a classic.  Not for euro-snobs, but an essential addition for the well-rounded gamer.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
Bang isn't necessarily a "bad" game, but it's the type of game I almost never want to play.  You have a secret identity as a Lawman, or type of bad guy, and an agenda to kill one or more of the types of other players in the game. On top of that, you also have a randomly assigned personality that adds a certain beneficial trait. 

Seems like a great setup!  So your guns are pointed at all other players in a mexican standoff, you have to figure out who to kill and not kill, and you'll get various cards and gear to do that effectively. 

Unfortunately, there's really no way to know who you're shooting at until the end of the game when they're dead.  The sheriff is known by default, but it's very common that players will misinterpret each others actions and misidentify their target.  This makes the game much less about skill, and the winner is often the person who just happens to be the least targeted person at the table.  

To make matters worse, the game doesn't always necessarily end quickly, and when you're dead you're just plain out of the game.  This means you can start with a nice happy group of people, and a bunch of them end up sitting around doing nothing but watching while the last 2 or 3 duke it out.  I'm just not a fan of exclusionary tactics.  
 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Bang can be enjoyable but it often over stays its welcome. It always feels like it drags on a bit too long. The icons on the cards require a lot of rulebook referencing                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                   for a game that feels like a social party game. Bang can be great fun with the right group of people.

RATING: 9

UPDATE: 1/30/08 (90 plays) - Plays well with any number over 5, especially once you get a competent renegade.  We will always be playing with the Dodge City expansion now (except with new players), since the new characters and cards add a lot to the game.

For games with 3 or 4 or players, we use the Posse variant, which is a lot of fun.  http://www.boardgamegeek.com/file/info/23136
Just watch out for Herb Hunter.

RATING: 4
I'm not terribly fond of player elimination, but I don't normally consider it a mortal sin of game design.  Except in this game.  Player elimination after that player has had a chance to do something or after multiple negative actions is one thing, but random player elimination based on a single card draw at the very beginning of the game is out of line.

The situation: I'm one of the characters that starts with three lives.  Right-hand opponent plays a dynamite.  Dynamite comes to me, I draw the wrong card, and lose three lives.  Boom, I'm out of the game.

RATING: 2
Unimpressive card game, quite chaotic, and you're always at the mercy of the draw. Good draws? You'll probably win. Bad draws? You'll probably eat lead early and sit around waiting for the game to end. And by 'good draws' I mean *especially* early on, I pity the poor bastard who ends up as the renegade, particularly in a 7 man game.

The most damning thing about this game is its potential length. Losing early can mean sitting around for the better part of an hour if the game plays long, and that is way, way too long for a game of this sort...even for the players, let alone the dead people.

RATING: 7
Bello ma poco longevo, dopo una decina di partite diventa difficile giustificare una partita riducendosi a un gioco da proporre unicamente alla componente neofita (o ignara) dei propri amici. Considerando il successo planetario (e forse anche in pò eccessivo) che il gioco ha avuto nel corso degli anni e le innumerevoli partite (di troppo) giocate da chi lo possiede, è certamente consigliato a chi prevede di giocarci con persone poco esperte... O, meglio ancora, bambini.

Resta comunque un gioco molto divertente, che nel bene e nel male ha contribuito a scrivere la storia del card-game made in italy in italia e nel mondo: se volete fare un reglo diverso a un amico non appassionato, con la "pallottola" andate sul sicuro!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Components: Quality cards. Nice, subtle artwork. I dislike that two cards could have the same function, but a different image (e.g. the two images for the Bang! cards). The iconography (hats, targets) is confusing. The distance rules are very difficult to keep track of. We had lots of rules questions, and were constantly referring back to the rule book.

Experience: It's Risk, it's Werewolf, it's vicious, it's epic. There is a major flaw, in that a game could potentially last forever (my second playing, with five people, lasted well over an hour). The mechanics are very simple once they are familiar. The character powers are great, adding a different personality to each player. The different objectives lead to some very interesting initial moves, before the streets erupt into open warfare. All the cards are useful at one point or another.

First Played: 2009-01-31
Last Played: 2009-01-31
Eagerness to Play Again: Within a year

Plays (2):
5 players: 2
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I love Bang!, and I own 2 well-used copies.  Each copy cost about $14.  I had thought I had lost my original copy, so I had bought another one.  Then I found my first copy.
Brent Clark introduced me to this game when it first came out.  He was looking for simple card games to play with his wife, but this one didn't quite fit that criteria.
I have bought 14 copies of Bang!, and resold several copies to friends or given them as Christmas gifts.  So lots of people around me know how to play Bang!
To make for a longer game, I have a house rule that you can't attack anyone until they have had their first turn.  That makes it a bit too long of a game, but it does give everyone a chance to put out some blue cards to protect themselves before being attacked.
I have printed off rules for 2-player and 3-player games, as well as FAQs.  I keep all of my characters from the various expansions together in one deck, so they are all available in every game I play.  I deal out 2 character cards to each player and let them choose which one they want to be.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Great game if you get enough people and you're all into it. Can be loads of fun. Finding that right group is the tricky part.

--------------------------------
UPDATE: Played this a bunch. Who cares about the art. This game is so fun it is crazy! This is a must have. 
Note the following: Try to play with 6-7 players. Has player elimination, a player can be eliminated without ever even participating in the gunfight. The eliminated player can be forced to wait a while, as the midgame can last, due to Beers and Saloons. 

Overall a must have must play game. Loads of fun. 
Rating 8.5
---------------------------------------
UPDATE: 3 months in. Ok, is there any way to get my play group to NOT ask for this game?? I'm like: I brought 10 games what do you wanna play? Bang! Honestly, can we try something new? No. This eats game night. I guess its bugging me because I always get killed first. 
Dodge city is a great addition here. 
Rated down to 8 because even though I'm getting bugged by it, it is still the only game where a player will laugh so hard he'll fall out of his chair, and the group will ask for it 100% of the time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In Bang! keren we terug naar het Wilde Westen. De Sheriff jaagt op de Renegade en de Outlaws. De Outlaws zijn vogelvrij verklaarde misdadigers die er niet voor terugdeinzen om de Sheriff een kopje kleiner te maken. De Sheriff krijgt echter hulp van de Deputy’s. Deze hulpsheriffen zouden hun eigen leven riskeren om de Sheriff in leven te houden. Tenslotte is er nog de Renegade. De Renegade probeert zich aan te sluiten bij de groep van de Outlaws of bij de groep van de Sheriff en zijn hulpje, maar uiteindelijk heeft de Renegade maar één doel: ervoor zorgen dat iedereen sterft zodat hij als enige overlevende overblijft in de Far West. De grote egoïst!

Lees verder op:
http://ditteriosracedoorspellenland.wordpress.com/2014/02/06/bang/

RATING: 6
Love the spaghetti western theme but player elimination ensures that at least one person will always have a crappy time. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
It sounds like a good idea for a game - in theory.  Unfortunately, actual play seems to fall short of the ideal.  When our group tried it, there ended up being very little strategy - everyone just started blazing away, and it didn't seem to matter too much at all as to who got shot.  In short, it was mostly just going through the motions turn after turn.  
The game does excel in one category, though.  Without question, it wins the Grand Prize for the dirtiest sounding table talk of any game out there - including the infamous "wood for sheep".  
PRIME EXAMPLE I'm playing a Bang card - Who are you banging? - I'm banging Bob - Well, I'm going to bang you twice - etc, etc, etc..., in multiple variations.  You have to wonder if the designers of this game deliberately meant it to be like that, or was it a genuine accident?  Either way,  it'll take some doing to ever top this one.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.25
The concept of this game is great: mix a little bit of werewolf with some strategic elements.  Even more than this, the game has great merit.  

But I have two big problems with the game.  The first, is that is takes a long time to play.  In fact, every time I've played it, it seems to overstay it's welcome.  This is a big problem as far as I'm concerned.  

My second problem is that there are too many rules to appeal to my non-gamer friends, and the game is a little light on interesting decisions to appeal to my gamer friends.  So this game hits a middle ground that does not really appeal to me or any of the people that I normally game with.  I know it's popular, but it must appeal to a different group than I usually hang out with. 

The bottom line: for what the game is, I want less rules (like Werewolf).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun, shoot-em-up card game for 4-7 players.  Each player takes on a role (sheriff, deputy, renegade, outlaw) with a different goal in the game.  Game turns are very simple, draw two cards, play/discard down to your hand size, and generally blast away at anything you can reach.  The hidden nature of the roles/goals do create some bluff and tension, but generally this game is a rollicking ride.  Well worth a look.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Fun Mafia style action. I like the Old West theme and the challenge of the Renegade, but the fact that almost random shooting on the part of the Sherrif can lead to victory as well as one who tries to determine his target's identities before he shoots them down became frustrating. Still, this game calls to me sometimes.

RATING: 7

The shorter duration also makes it more appealing as a game to take out and play for us busy college students.  Also how it's slightly similar to Mafia (known as Werewolf here at BGG), a game that most of us learned in the dorms.

RATING: 5.5
A playing of Bang! has always gone the same way for me.

Someone suggests it, I look forward to playing it, recalling that I rather enjoy it.

Then we play, the same off-color "jokes" that weren't really funny the first time get used.

The least popular person (or the one who won the last game) gets taken out.

I look forward to the game ending.

I wonder why I looked forward to playing it in the first place.

But then, the next time it is brought up, this whole story repeats itself.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
One of the first successful hidden identity games for larger groups of (7) players.  I am probably giving this a much higher score than it really deserves as I can see how this was very fresh and an industry-changer when it first came out way back in 2002.  However by 2016 standards, the game is broken and completely supplanted by newer games (such as it’s own re-implemented “Samurai Sword” game in 2012).  I would assume a lot of players still play this more for nostalgia reasons than actual game-play.  If you are considering “Bang!”, I highly recommend trying its younger sibling “Samurai Sword” first: that game plays smoother, is more streamlined and does NOT have player-elimination.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A multi-player game that actually works with 5-8! I recommend getting the Dodge City expansion though -- it makes for a more balanced game (another expansion/patch <grin>)

RATING: 6
The setting and basic flow of this game is quite okay. However, unlucky players may find themselves eliminated after their first turn (or even before that!). The player roles are quite unbalanced as well, since outlaws only need to kill the sheriff, while the renegade has to kill all other players, and even in a particular order to boot! Also, the game suffers from excessive language-independency: all card actions are explained by symbols which are cryptic and hard to understand.

RATING: 7.5
I played many 7 player games of Bang! during one weekend in 2005 with a group of friends. It was enough to know that it was a card game which I wanted in my game collection and is ideal to have for a large group of people. I am not too fond of card games in general, but BANG! is one exception.

Having different possibilities for which character you choose is interesting. Each character has its own power which can be a factor on how well a player can do during a game. Some character are better than others.

Different characters, different roles you can do. Lots of possibilities.

I would want to play the game again sometime soon, hopefully with 7. Possibly with family rather than my usual gaming friends. I would be curious to know their opinion of this game. Looking forward to my next game.

Got 2 copies.

10 plays since recording games played.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I used to like BANG a lot more, but a couple issues have really made the game less desirable to play recently.  First, it's usually way too long for what it's supposed to be.  It should be a quick playing game, but everyone ends up playing a lot more slowly than it should be.  Also, every time it's brought out, it attracts 8 people, which makes quite a long game.  Furthermore, all the expansions seem a little unnecessary.  I would take the first expansion and that's it.  The game also unfortunately suffers from the teaching.  It's a simple game, but you almost always have to teach it again, and getting all 8 players to know the symbols can be an annoyance.  It still has a nostalgic place for me, but unfortunately I think other games have outshined it over the years.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Bang probably win the award for "game I am most conflicted about."

On one hand, I love the theme. Come on! Spaghetti Westerns! Really!

On the other hand, my issues with the game are many:

1) The deduction element of the game is either absent or aggravating. Basically everyone just starts shooting at anyone they can shoot at because they can.

2) The cards. I know it was a choice to keep the cards "language neutral" but it's a pain in the neck to explain the cards time and again to people that haven't played the game regularly.

3) The card effects. Now I'm a role-player from way back, so calculating all sorts of bonehead modifiers is second nature to me, but just try to explain to someone that due to the cards in front on them, you can be three spaces away from them but they are only one space away from you.

In short, this is one of those games that has a way steeper learning curve than a "light" game should have. I keep looking at this game on my shelf and wondering if I should get rid of it, but I end up keeping it anyway.

If I get to see the newest edition and the cards are easier to explain, I may change this rating.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.8
Overall, a fun game, which suffers from similar problems as Werewolf: early elimination. It is slightly less random, but that comes down to who the Sheriff is, since he can sometimes eliminate someone even before he has the chance to act. And there can be a lot of downtime between two turns.

On the other hand, there aren't that many games that aren't complicated nor long, and that lets 8-12 players play and have a blast. It gets old soon, depending on the playerbase.

RATING: 8
Bang! is best with 5 or more players, so I rarely play anymore. There are a lot of minor rules that are not clearly spelled out and can cause debates mid-game, it is not the most friendly game to beginners. Also, games are fairly long for a card game which can make getting eliminated in the first round or two really frustrating. I have played several hundred games of Bang! and still really enjoy it. I would say it is a must-have if you like a variety of card games.

RATING: 7
Bang suffers from the same problem as Munchkin: it doesn't hit its sweet spot until you have 5 or more players, but by then the playing time starts to increase drastically for each additional player. With 7 or 8 players, the game can go well over half an hour unless everyone is playing quickly (which is really how the game should be). 

However, if you have a willing, exuberant group, playing this game along with Cowpoker and The Good, the Bad, and the Munchkin will give you a fun Western-themed evening.

[b]Update:[/b] Raised from a 6 to a 7. If you can get enough players, this really is a lot of fun.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
A fun group card game for 4-7 players (best with 6 or 7), where you play roles as sheriff, deputies and outlaws, trying to shoot each other and figure out who is who.  Great bluffing and interaction.  Drawback: player elimination (but not a concern if players familiar with the game play quickly).  The two & three player variants from the designer also work well.  We sometimes play that nobody can play "take that" cards in the first round, to prevent a player from being "crippled" and out of the game without having a chance to do anything.  New players should buy the third edition game, because it has text on the cards explaining special abilities rather than icons.  Theme might be problematic for some folks (just rename the "Beer" card as the "Root Beer" card!).

Also have expansions:
[gameid=20237] (note: the next card should be face up so players can prepare for it, says the designer [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/73639#73639]here[/url].  Also check the [url=http://www.bang.cz/download/faq/FAQ_a_fistful_of_cards_eng.pdf]FAQ and Errata[/url].)
[gameid=60381]
[gameid=63490]

RATING: 1

This because in this game, when playng 5 or more, a player could be killed quickly ... so quickly that him/her will not play!

An example to explain a "1st round-killed-without play": 
- 1st player plays 'indians' (5th player is hit because if without a "bang");
- 2nd player plays 'indians' (5th player is hit because if without a "bang");
- 3rd player plays "bang" against 5th player (5th player is hit if without a "missed");
- 4th player plays "bang" against 5 player (5th player is hit if without a "missed"). 
... and finally ...
- 5th/last player is "KILLED WITHOUT PLAY", if without any card to protect himself!!!

Now: i call "game" the thing the lets you "play" with it ... Bang isn't a game!!!

RATING: 4
* Played 10+ times. Good game for bigger group, can be as short as 20 minutes. Plays best with 7, but enjoyable with all numbers (less players goes by quicker so the duration-to-enjoyment ratio stays the same. A bit like Frank's Zoo with lightness, and quasi-teaming of players; a bit like Citadels in roles assigned and special abilities for each character. The designer also has 2-player and 3-play variants now and, though lighter and less interesting, are lightning quick, and still amusing, and a great way to introduce the game to a beginner.

(Sold to UBCVnsa)

RATING: 6
So many of my gaming buddies have this game that I get to play this regularly.  After a few plays, my impression improved somewhat.  Bearing in mind this is a light game meant to be played with some attitude, there are a few points going for it.  First of all, there is a genuine challenge in winning with the renegade.  The hidden roles at the start of the game remind me of 5-player Tarot, and the quicker the sherif finds his vice determines how and where the game will go.  I tried some of the expansions and they really do add something new.

RATING: 4
I would play the dice version of Bang any day over the card version. My experience with the card version has not been great. =-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
got the core came, and loooved it, so I got the Bullet, but I was disappointed because I found the expansions to not be very fun or useful at all.  The best thing about the Bullet is the added number of characters to choose from. Though several of them work only with expansions. you still get another dozen or so to choose from.

The Bullet lets you play with 8 players instead of the max of 7 in the core game, but a deck of cards and a little creativity lets you play with 8 in the core game anyway.  One of the expansions of the Bullet solves the one draw back of Bang - getting eliminated early.  I have played a few games with 7 players where one person was killed before they even got their first turn.  Then they get to sit there for the next half hour watching people play.  It sucks.  The Bullet expansion allows killed players to have a go as a sort of "ghost" that gets a normal turn, but disappears from existence every time its not their turn.  However, this is something you can also do without actually owning any expansions.  Get the core game and you won't be disappointed.

RATING: 7.5
Everyone new to this loves this. Who doesn't like killing their friends? Great, light fun. Great that it goes up to 8 with expansion. We often seem to have 1 too many for Citadels/Bohnanza and this one seems more fun for the masses. 

A little bit of a learning curve for non-gamers, but most people get completely comfortable by the 3rd-4th round - and they always want to keep playing - once they get past decoding the symbols/get familiar with the action cards and figuring out that distance thing (which is the most difficult thing in the game for new players).

My least favorite thing about this game is the player elimination but often, people are into the game enough that watching their team try to survive/win is still extremely gripping.

My roommate developed this 2-player variant that works well and we'll probably play that a few more times.

RATING: 7
Bang! is slow to learn, but after a couple of years of annual play (at Christmas, when visiting family) it's finally sunk in to the level where it's enjoyable.  The theme caries over some of the early difficulty, but the hard part is learning to play tactically and not to just shoot the person next to you because there's nothing else to do.  While you're trying to guess the identity of the other players a mechanism for communication other than shooting them may help improve the start of the game, as it is, you either fire or feel like you're waiting for tactical information that might never arrive.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Rules Complexity: :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar:
Strategic Depth: :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Luck Factor :star::star::star::star::halfstar:
Negotiation Factor: :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Amount of Downtime: :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Fiddliness: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Component Quality: :star::star::star::star::star:
Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::star:
"Take That" Conflict: :star::star::star::star::star:
Theme Integration: :star::star::star::star::star:

I think this is a great game for a bunch of heavier gamers that are looking for a filler.  But I've had problems playing this with newbies - there are a lot of rules for something this light.  You have to play it with the "spaghetti western" attitude of not taking things too seriously, and play your cards pretty quick.  If you're agonizing over which card to play, you're probably playing this in a different spirit than was intended.
UPDATE: My kids love this game, and it is a lot more fun than it should be for someone who doesn't care for a lot of chaos.  I'm bumping it up a notch in the ratings.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Because everyone's gun has a "range", everyone starts the game only able to shoot their immediate neighbors until they get a better gun or horse. This prevents everyone from ganging up on one person at the beginning of the game normally. I like this.

I rated this a 7 in 2009, but by 2012 I was wise to its ways. It's really hard to teach to a certain type of person. Some people don't know what to do strategy wise, the concept of take-that is lost on them. Non gamers struggle with the gamer logic, like how this game has hit points and how the range mechanic works. The deduction part proves boring. Finally, Bang! often devolves into a slugfest at the end between the sheriff and someone else. This game is outgunned by Family business because its harder to learn and not very interesting. Resistance is a much better deduction game. I'm moving it to a 3. 

Another thing. I play with a patient group. When three players are left, the Sheriff will just sit there passing the whole time while the two others duke it out, because of course one of them is a deputy and the other is a renegade. When the winner claws his or her way out of the dust-up the full health Sheriff just blows them away.

I sold my copy in 2014. I've heard that Bang: The Dice Game is good though. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
3-7 players
Card Game
Players take on hidden roles of law or criminal along with being a unique character.
Cards are used to play items, shoot at people, or other defensive/offensive actions.
Sheriff and Deputies try to kill the outlaws and renegade, outlaws try to kill everyone else; renegade tries to kill the sheriff last.
20-30 min

RATING: 7
The Spaghetti Western card game so thematic the cards are in Italian.  Well, in earlier editions at least, but that's good enough for me.  I like the Are You A Werewolf? style game play of trying to figure out who's who a lot more when it has guns and random cards.  Not a game to be taken seriously but always a hoot, especially with a full complement of seven players.  Avoid the expansions like the plague, however, as they serve no purpose but to make the game longer and less fun.  Okay, some of the new characters are fun, but that's about it.

RATING: 7
I've now played it several times with different numbers of players. It is great fun. I think the more players the better, but have not tried it with less. With 4, the Outlaw might be at a disadvantage. I would consider balancing this by giving the Sheriff 1 less card (to a minimum of 1) per life point. The main consideration for this game is the mix of players. Get the right players and it is an 8.5. Get the wrong mix and it is a boring 3! With fun-loving players who are not in the mood for serious fare this will be a hit.

RATING: 6
Finally got to play this one.  Six players was good light fun.  Plan to try with the expansions.    Seems like it would suffer greatly with less than five or six, though.  

Update: Played with all the expansions (that now come together in a cool-looking bullet-shaped box).  Moves fast, no heavy thinking involved.  Great with six players.

Update again: Slight downgrade to 6.  Defensive play can cause the game to drag, and combined with early player elimination(s), this can be really bad and turned my group off of the game.

RATING: 6
Purchased 9/01/2005


Nice, light filler.  Some kills feel so anti-climatic..."Oh, I'm dead.  Hmm..."

Plus, deducing roles isn't that difficult.


Needs the full compliment if 7--gets worse as the number of players decrease.  The 4-player version is particularly awful--why would you even bother to play it that way?

It's marketing, man...putting "requires 7" on the box is sales suicide.


UPDATE:  Played it twice since then, and it still manages to be a ton of fun.  Watched a player blow himself up with dynamite, another player constantly get put in jail, beer and bullets flying everywhere...this is a great game.

The icons can cause some problems getting used to (blame that on the ALMIGHTY LANGUAGE INDEPENDENCE~!) but it doesn't take too long to puzzle through.



UPDATE:  Oddly, this gets a little less fun every time I play it.  Those first few games were hilarious.  Maybe we just have had a bad run the past couple of games.

RATING: 2.5
Barely acceptable only for 5 or 7 players.  The deduction part of this game only really comes into play when there are 7 players, or after all Outlaws are dead and you are looking for the Renegade.  It REALLY sucks when you're out of the game before you have your [-]second[/-] first turn.  Ten minutes of waiting followed by 20 minutes of waiting for the others to finish their game!  Fun!  I also had a game in which I was jailed the first turn, and the second turn, and blown up with dynamite on the third.  Exciting!  The decisions are rarely difficult and card draw is a MUCH more significant factor than any of those decisions.

I so very much wanted to like this, but it only disappointed.

RATING: 7
My gateway game; deception is very fun, relatively fast, definitely plays better with more people (6 is perfect - 1 sheriff, 1 vice, 1 renegade, 3 outlaws), but depending on players downtime may get excessive with more than 6. As long as the beginning has little to no stalemate, game should be fast and fluid. Not a game you should expect to win at (or taken personally if eliminated), but if you can overcome these small downsides the game should be fun.

RATING: 4
Bang! has a problem: It's too predictable and you will often know not just who got each role but also the aproximated content of their hand in less than a turn. And since one influences the other, once you know that about a player you can easily see deduce what the other players are doing.

So the game ends up being quite shallow as efficiency trumps bluffing.

For that reason I only bring it out when I have new people around.

One of the best gamer for funny accents, tough. :)

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[JAN 09] [Rating: 6]
There is something very attractive with this spaghetti western theme, especially when the cards are written in Italian. And I sure did enjoy the game at first, just for the sake of the hilariously well made theme and the cards alone. But underneath I found a game that at the same time is very frustrating.

To explain this to new players you have to go through all the symbols, which is unpractical. Some of the symbols even have a book icon where you have to look in the rulebook to understand. The learning curve of the game is steep; still the game is quite random and light.

While each individual turn is quite fast, it will drag on when playing with many players. Still there is most fun out of the game with many players as there are more to deduce. The deduction is in itself nice, but it becomes pretty apparent after a while.

If it is over fast, I have probably enjoyed the game. It can however be hard to kill another player, especially when you are out of good cards. When the game drag, it is not fun, especially for the players who are eliminated.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
What can I say...I started the BANG! revolution... This game is pretty much the catalyst that started my insane gaming addiction. I don't know why, but I randomly came upon this and played it with friends. We must have had 2 months straight of weekend BANG! gaming till 4-5am. I'm rather proud that within a month, 3-4 of my friends had the game. They were mad when I wasn't around to play it, therefore, they couldn't play it either. I'm happy to say I was the cause for the G.P. staying sold out of this game for over a month. Then Munchkins came along...

Oh, and if my younger brother asks...tell him it's rootbeer. That's the only problem I kinda have with this game. I wish there was a younger kid's addition. (I know, this is very impractical) Fortunately, Nathen still thinks it's rootbeer yet...

RATING: 6
Bang! is a relatively light, chaotic game.  For being a light game, the rules take a bit of time to digest (particularly for those unfamiliar with MtG/CCG type games) and your first game will probably go slowly.  

The cards are on good quality stock, but the art is certainly nothing to write home about and doesn't add much to the game.

The game can be fun, but the special abilities of the characters seem unbalanced.
