=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Gil, Marcos
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A sör gyógyít, a nők meglopnak.
A poros vadnyugati kisváros csendjét, eddig nyugodt életét pisztolylövések zaja zavarja meg. Sheriffünknek nincs könnyű dolga, ki kell deríteni ki vagy kik törnek az életére. Tényleg a Dalton banda tagjai, vagy a híres Névtelen renegát vagy csak önkéntes helyettese pufogtat a főutcán? Közben folyik a sör, táncolnak a lányok, érkeznek a postakocsik. A város nagy túlélője, a Koporsókészítő pedig már méretre vágta az alapanyagot.
Játékosszámtól függően a Sheriff, a Banditák, a Renegát vagy Renegátok, illetve a Helyettes vagy Helyettesek próbálják meg céljaikat elérni ebben a kártyajátékban. Próbálsz felszerelkezni, védekezni a lövések, betévedő indiánok, polgárháborús hatcsövű gatling ellen, de vigyáznod kell a szép hölgyekre is.
A játék elején mindenki megkapja titkos szerepét, majd a Sheriff felfedi magát és kezdődik a tánc (farkasokkal). Körödben kártyát húzol, majd a kezedben lévő lapokban rejlő lehetőségeket kombinálva törsz sikerre. Általában vagy felhúzod, amit szeretnél vagy nem. Így Fortuna istenasszony is domináns szerepet játszik a fordulók során.
Sajnos minél többször sebesülsz meg, annál kevesebb az esélyed gyorsan talpra állni és ezt a lehetőséget ellenfeleid sem fogják kihagyni. Egy-egy jól megválasztott karakterrel (a játékban vannak hasznosabb és kevésbé hasznosabbak is) esélyeid megnőnek.
A játék számomra egyik nagy negatívuma, amikor az első körök egyikében a többiek kilőnek, majd egyes esetekben nagyon hosszú holtidő telik el a játék vége előtt. Természetesen valakinek ez nem probléma, én azonban szeretem minimálisra venni a holtidőt, ha ez lehetséges. Ilyen szempontból a játék kockásított változatát jobban szeretem. Valamint bizonyos játékosszámnál (kifejezetten 4 főnél) a játék amúgy is törékeny egyensúlya teljesen megbomlik.
Partijátéknak mindenképpen ideális, főleg, mivel magyar nyelven is elérhető. Ha van lehetőség a választásra, számomra marad a kocka Bang. Bár itt a már megjelent kiegekben található további lehetőségek is változtathatnak a megfelelő változat kiválasztásában.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5

RATING: 6
It is hard for me to give very high marks to a game you can lose before you get a turn, but it is hard for me to give low marks to a game that takes Werewolf and makes it even cooler. Far from balanced, but tons of fun. Surprisingly quick to learn with a good teacher, but don't get bogged down explaining every card. Let people play it and see what it does. Be lighthearted, and don't be afraid to shoot your best friend and you will have a great time with this. 

UPDATE:
This has fallen in the rankings for me as the Bang Dice Game delivers much the same experience without overstaying its welcome at higher player counts.

RATING: 6
This game isn't as bad as I thought it was going to be (e.g. it's not as bad as Cash and Guns).  But it does have some flaws:
- just like in Mafia, once you get knocked out of the game, all you can do is sit and watch (or start another game)
- it's not that deductive of a game as you might think, since we all start with no information, and we eventually start to attack someone who might be our ally
- some combinations of cards and roles are too good at defence and poor at offence, and when that happens, the game can go on forever

RATING: 8
[Initial Impression: 8]
A great game with a larger group (5-7).  There does seem to be a tilt toward the sheriff and deputy winning, and the renegade is clearly the most daunting role to play.  Drawbacks are that some character powers seem a bit over the top compared to the others, the overly strong position of the sheriff if seated next to a deputy or the renegade, and the possibility of early elimination for one or more players. But the game is loads of fun with the right group, reasonably fast, and holds lots of tension and flavor.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
The pleasure-density of this game is so off the charts I swear the cards are made of an alloy of Ununoctium and molten fun.  Yes, it has player elimination.  Yes, it is almost pure chaos.  So play it like a party game—we've rarely had a game go beyond 30 minutes.  Remember, it's called [i]BANG![/i], not "Marshall Resources".  

UPDATE:  I've seen the Renegade win plenty of big games.  It's tough—it's the most difficult role to play—but it just means you have to be extra double-plus crafty with a corpse's poker face and expert timing.  Quit whining and embrace the challenge.

UP-UPDATE:  Huh—it turns out the 4p game is actually interesting...  The Renegade knows from the get-go who the two Outlaws are and the Sheriff can start shooting willy-nilly on the first turn.  Once the first Outlaw goes down there's an interesting dynamic where the remaining Outlaw can offer to help the Sheriff to keep from getting double-teamed...

And, if nothing else, it goes [i]quick![/i]

RATING: 6.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Random, funny and paranoic... The problem is that it´s not very strategical, and gets repetitive after some plays.

This game is just OK, but has been overrated and hyped in the past because the "role mechanic" was trendy with Eurogamers.

Normally I don't mind player elimination, but in "Bang!" this is a big issue. A player will be likely killed in the first turns, (without deserving it), and then the game will drag on forever because the game offers no incentive to attacking other players, and turtling is the best tactic.

Car Wars: the Cardgame makes the same in less time and solves the player elimination problem (the duels are so quick that you don't mind being eliminated).

UPDATE: Playing with roles can be funny at first, but then you realize that the Renegade cannot win, and every play tends to be the same. Try to play without roles, everyone versus everyone, as "Mag-Blast" or "Car Wars".

- egyrészt csak gyakorlott játékosokkal jó játszani

- a kiesők sokáig csak unatkoznak

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
A decent negotiation/traitor deduction game.  Strategy is fairly straightforward without any expansions (always try to eliminate anybody who might not be on your side, as its better to eliminate a possible ally than leave a possible outlaw alive).  "Distance" (from being on a horse) and ranges of weapons is an interesting mechanic.  Some cards are much more powerful than others, so there's quite a bit of luck... and if you get eliminated early (e.g. in the first round due to bad starting hand, too weak OR too strong of an identity, and awkward position relative to the Sheriff), or can't shoot anyone because your neighbours are on horses and you can't draw a weapon or scope, it can be boring.  Unfortunately the dominant early strategy is "attack everyone in range", and it can take a while before anyone can really deduce anything.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
After a single play, it was so-so.  Seems that certain roles have a far better chance of living than others.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
1st played Oct 10th, 2007. Rules explaination 10min, length 45min. There are so many types of cards, it takes a while to determine what each do. A gameplay or two is needed to get acquainted. Screams cheatsheet. Played w/6 players who previously played. I played sherrif since it's easiler for newbies to learn. Game recommended for larger group of players. Each player is dealt a character and a role. All chars have special abilities. Roles: Sherrif, deputy, outlaw or renegade. Sherrif also gets one extra hit point and starts game. On your turn you draw a card and then play cards. Cards can be equipment to allows you to shoot beyond the player to your left or right. There are action cards that let you draw cards as well. You can only play one "bang" card (shoots one person). They can play a miss card. You can also play a duel card which allows you to play bang cards until you run out or you finally hit. You can also play a whiskey (heal) card. Hand limit is the number of hit points you have left. Sherrif wins by killing the outlaws and renegades. Outlaws win by killing sherrif. I'd recommend giving this a try if you know someone who has it and have enough players to support the game. It's a good fun game, however it may test your patience with learning the ropes.

RATING: 3
Ultimately, Bang is fun but deeply flawed.  The player elimination can be very quick (and foul-tasting), luck of the draw is a bit overwhelming, some of the characters have balance issues, and the endgame is quite frankly, retarded.  The two remaining players simply enter into a competition of "draw the right combo" to end it.  If there was a way to diminish these blemishes, my rating would sky-rocket.  Not too bad as is though which is an accomplishment considering the downfalls.

Update:  The downfalls do in fact ruin this stupid game.  Someone is always garunteed to get shat upon whether by dying before they get a turn or by being put in jail over and over again.  The game can also lock up pretty easily and the luck of the draw is highly annoying for such a long game with player elimination.  The renegade is also impossible to play most of the time.  Ugh, I'd need some serious convincing to ever try this mess again any time in the near to distant future.  Blech.

RATING: 3
If you are going to make a social deduction, hidden role party game, for doge's sake make it possible to figure out a damn role before someone dies. On top of that, even if someone is that special kind of stupid to tip their hand before 2-3 players have been eliminated, you could be in taken out by random BS like dynamite. Or Indians. Or anyone having a bad day.

Expansion does not make this more tolerable. Artificial deck/hand size fattening with the all-too-pleasant effect of making yourself a target if the effect is that strong. Play a better game that actually generates engaging table talk, like Shadow Hunters or the new Emergence. This also made me want to play Deception in HK...and I do not even enjoy it. Leave this old trash for the kids that do not know any better.

RATING: 5
A fun concept for a game, and I definitely like the western theme. However, the game (as I last played it a while ago, maybe they've adjusted the rules some) is pretty broken without having some significant house rules added to the game. Actions that can be taken are dictated too much by one's position in the circle (which is totally random), and the game can take FOREVER in some instances. And when people are knocked out within the first turn of a 2 hour game...

It just doesn't work as a light filler-type game in most circumstances. And it doesn't have the muscle to make a long game worthwhile. It can be fun, but I'd rather take my chances on another game almost always.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
What can I say?  Bang! is great.

It captures the feeling of the Spaghetti Western, is different every time, can be played with lots of players, and a game is pretty quick.  We can usually play this one twice before moving on to another game.

I HIGHLY RECOMMEND using bullet shells as life counters, especially since the bullets on the back of the cards have a habit of sliding accidently during gameplay (We reserve five silver ones for the Sheriff).

If I have ONE gripe, it's that the horse cards are confusing.  The description on the cards cause us to have a hard time remembering if the horse is taking you clear of danger, or faster to catch up to someone you're chasing.  Often in our games, someone has to argue, "Naw, tha's a runnin' TO horse, not a runnin' AWAY horse!"  Simply having the artwork on the cards showing a horse and rider running away from a posse, or running after a varmint would remedy this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Wow, we have played this a whole lot.  A big hit with teens, especially.  I have finally, after fours years, have gotten a bit tired of it.  But I won't lower my rating, it held up so well for so long.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Buen juego que ha envejecido mal por la mecánica de eliminación de jugadores.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Cards game where every player has a unique role that, except for the sheriff, remain as a secret until the end of the game. Every role has a different way of winning. The role is combined with a unique character. There are characters that fit every role but there are others that is just the opposite. If, when dealing the characters, you receive 2 characters that don't really fit with your role, you will have a problem.
The game is easy to explain, easy to play and it may be fun, and I explain this, but it depends on how fast the players play. If you have one truly slow player, it is a nightmare, because the mechanics have been thought for playing fast. 
Bang has one of the worst rules that can apply to any game, which is the "sofa" rule, you are dead, ok go and watch tv for a while. Having said that, in this game is not as critical as in Risk, for instance. If the killed player is the sheriff, the game is over and a new round can be played, if not, it shouldn't take more than 15 minutes to finish the round, which should be fine.
Positive:
1. Easy to explain and play
2. Recommended for every type of player
3. The secret roles are a good idea, however, it doesn't take too long to identify every one
4. Many rounds can be played in a short time
Negative:
1. The character of the sheriff has to suit the role, if not, the round can be finished even before the sheriff has played 2 turns
2. A minimum of 4 players is required
3. The "sofa" rule, even thought it is not as critical in this game
4. The risk of having an "slow player", this is not on the game but on the group of players, but, please, play fast this game, you shooting guns, not writing poems (with all due respect)
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
VENTA: Bang (Edge 4º edición), como nuevo, sin estrenar, precio 12 euros
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I've heard some complaints about the limited ability of being able to affect only the players sitting next to you, but I actually like this rule. It makes the theme of having short range and long range weapons make a lot more sense. Also, the not knowing who each player is can be quite fun- unless you're playing with someone who just doesn't get their role. Often a hilarious game! Not as good as Resistance, but a lot of fun none the less.

RATING: 3
This game is a lot like the game Mafia (Mafia is not a board game in case you're wondering) but it is less fun.  In Mafia you can try to convince everyone why you are or are not part of the Mafia.  Plus, the killing is done in secret whereas in Bang! the shooting is all public.

To me it is too easy to figure out who is playing which role in Bang! - the Renegade is the only player with any ambiguity to it.  Also, you are so limited in who you can attack and when you can attack that it becomes boring.

This game is terribly tedious and is only good for playing with people who don't enjoy any other games.  Please don't make me play this game again!

the shooting range is a nice touch...

Sherif playing first isn't really an advantage, as he's going to shoot in the blind, possibly hurting one of his own crew.  And can you really pass on the opportunity to shoot?  you might be dead next turn...

Downtime.  Games can be long, and you can die fast.  Watching isn't as fun as playing

Rules are missing some things...you can't have two weapons...but can you have two horses ?  It is not specificly said that you can't have 2 or more of the same/similar equipment.

beer cards\saloon cards only played once


player aids for card symbols



I should note that we house-rule that you can Dynamite anybody instead of placing it in front of you for a turn. This puts it into play one turn sooner, and introduces a little more strategy into an otherwise randomized event. I think this adds a lot to the game and makes it play a bit faster



3) DEFINITELY get rid of the Saloon and other non-original Beer cards,
4) Allow the variation to throw the Dynamite elsewhere rather than it starting in front of you,
5) Only allow one horse per player just like the rules limit one weapon per player,

RATING: 4
2013-08-11

Initial Rating: 6.5 (August 2008)

Bang! Could be a very good game for many people, but not for me. I dislike the theme, the game is too long for what it offers, if you are killed first it really sucks, moreover if you are dead BEFORE you take your first turn. It offers no interesting decisions, still it can be fun with the right group. However, the worst offender for me is that Bang! has lots and lots of downtime, that killed the game for me.  I also dislike the prison card, in more games it sucks to lose a turn, in Bang! is criminal as you will probably be dead before you play again.

The hidden roles are ok, the Renegade has it very hard to win a game, I have yet not seen that.

Bottom line, I love hidden roles games but I will do my best to stay away from this game, I prefer to play The Resistance or BSG if there is time. I won’t ever buy this game.

RATING: 2
I think this game totally sucks.  It's hard for newbies to figure out the symbols on the cards, people can get eliminated early and have to wait around for an eternal time, possibly, there's a highly variable game length, too much hidden information for everyone except knowing the id. of the Sheriff, etc.  I have no desire to play it and the only reason it gets rated here is I have been forced to endure multiple playings of this when I was unable to prevail on others in the group to try another game.  So I imagine I will be roped into playing it again some time (usually at sessions where I can't leave since I am the host), but I seriously don't see anything to cause my rating to go up.  What's weird is that the company that produced this "hit" (pardon the pun), DaVinci Games, has recently produced a really fine game, Leonardo da Vinci, and that's one I will be playing alot.

RATING: 5
People think that there is a strong deduction/bluffing factor in this game but it's absolutely false. Everyone's role becomes clear in two turns. The rest is a matter of almost brainless shooting. Who draws the best cards wins. And also games can be long, so hope to not be eliminated in the early stage. (Comment based on uncountable plays including tournaments). Still it's good to have in collection because it usually appeals to new non-boardgamers and hence can be the starting point to give birth to new boardgamers.

RATING: 5.5
A wild, wild west card game.  My first problem is the western.  It's really a product of a different generation, where old white guys that drank whiskey or milk ran Mexican bandits out of town.  Remember the gold ol' days when you could just shoot a guy for looking at you funny?  Uh no and those were the good ol' days.  The card game actually captures that.  You're shooting at people that could be outlaws or they could be your own deputy.  Knowing which is which would make shooting the other guy not as challenging.

RATING: 7
I think that a game like Bang! is best played with nongamers.  There is a lot of randomness in the card draws and the length of time the game takes is a little too long for the amount of gaming satisfaction provided.  However, with nongamers the system is quite different (the mafia-esque properties, though it is still pretty easy to figure out who's who) and the amount of luck and gametime aren't as bothersome.  It is unusually rules-heavy for such a light game, and it takes a while for new players to figure out the symbols used on the cards.  But it can be pretty fun as long as players don't mind direct confrontation.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
This is an overall fun game, and my inner teenage boy loves the innuendo of banging every other player repeatedly and without remorse. The player count is a drawback for my game situations - this game is most fun with more people, while I am often playing in groups of 3 or 4 (and it is a 4 player minimum). It is pretty easy to get to the table - the pun of being a literal Spaghetti Western, fun theme, and relatively straightforward rules make it appealing and easy to start. 

I'm not totally convinced by the part-cooperative/part-competitive playstyle. So far, games have either seemed like a case of everyone ganging up on the Sheriff, or a pointless free-for-all massacre, which, while thematically logical, don't make for a very fun game especially if you're on the losing end. This also tends to create unbalanced play; the vast majority of games we've played have ended with the Sheriff dying. However, this might be due to poor strategizing on the part of the players, since we usually play with fairly casual groups who don't get too deep into the strategy.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Tiring of this game a little bit, heard dice version is better.

RATING: 7
- 5-7 player
- Weight: Light
- Genre: Party
- Length: Short

Bang is another deduction game but with some more interactive elements (shooting each other) that make it different. Each player gets a old west themed character that are all fun but sadly some are far-and-away better than others creating imbalance. Not recommended at all with less than 5 people but quite a bit of fun with more than five. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
The good: Western theme. Players also must use deduction to figure out the various roles.

The Bad: The average game takes too long for what it is. On top of that, once in a while the game goes on for multiple hours. Players can be eliminated early on in a long game. The cards are fiddly - it takes multiple games to remember all the effects.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Very fun - takes the foundation of a faster, more cuthroat and complicated version of "Werewolf" and piles on the western flavour like so much tasty, picante BBQ mesquite flavour.

Pretty wild game that can be quickly taught and quickly played. Great opener - gets the blood flowing without a lot of need for deep thinking. I unfortunately made a really bad rules misinterpretation about the "Jail" card which coloured my opinion of the game until I found out I had been doing it all wrong. Much better now.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
Fits into a pocket, a heap of people may play, and one is rarely not sober enough to pull of a somewhat reasonable play.

Yes, you may die before you've had a turn, yes, your team mates may sometimes be stupid. Who cares? The next game is 20 minutes away, and all may change.

Bang is a good game, one I warmly recommend; it captures a cinematic shootout well, and is loads of fun.

RATING: 7
12-14-2007: I like one thing about Bang!  The theme of Spaghetti Westerns is dripping all over.  There are some clever mechanics, like the role selection, but ultimately, the player elimination and extremely high chaos factor (a player can be eliminated before getting a turn!) make it not my scene.  A good pub game -- would prob. get a 6 in that context.

2016 update: This is the context in which I most often play games, so BANG! now gets a 7.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
A light very luck-based card playing game. While the theme is cool and for a game of its genre such luck-based cards as the dynamite can be excused, the problem is the beginning of the game either diverges into 2 scenarios:
1. people take random potshots at each other, causing people to attack each other without knowing their allegience; the sheriff twiddles his thumbs  not really having an incentive to do anything.
2. The outlaws make their identity very clear by attacking the sheriff (yes the renegade can add a little bit of confusion, but the sheriff potentially wants to kill him/her eventually anyways). The deputies help out the sheriff, secret identities are effectively revealed.

It is very hard for the renegade to win this game (in fact, I've played a game where the renegade killed me as the sheriff in frustration prior to killing my deputy. This caused an awkward situation of the outlaws winning despite all of them being dead).
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A beer and pretzels type game. Fun with the right people from time to time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
A downside is that you can get out of the game very early (I've been "shot" to "death" and/or riddled with Indian arrows on a couple occasions before I even got a turn).  Another downside (for some) is if the game takes an hour or more.  However, if the outlaws try to start making their move earlier on it usually makes the game faster.  I don't mind it either way.  I enjoy the role play and trying to figure out who is on whose teams, trying to make the opponent think I am am on their team while letting the Sheriff know (very subtly, but fairly) that I am on HIS team, and the normal interaction that can occur during this game.  Should not be a 'sit-and-think-and-never-talk-to-the-other-people-at-the-table type of game.

We started handing out three character cards at the beginning and we each get to select two from those three.  Dual-characters.  Yes.  "Slab-Willy-the-Kid" Combo?  Yes, please. :) Haven't looked back. 

 Great for witty people and more thoughtful (and patient) people.  Great for people who love the Old Western theme.  A chance to live out your dream of participating in an action packed Louis L'Amour story! 

Used to play this almost every day in college (18-24 year olds mostly).  Typically, most of us (of about 15-20 people) would prefer 6-7 players (sometimes more), but most would be up for a game with a minimum of 5.  You can mess around with 3 or 4 people, but...that is more for the 'diehards' and not an accurate reflection of the game in its purest form.

Hope this has been helpful to some.   Lock and load!!!

P.S. If anyone is in the NW Washington area and wants to play... Let me know!!!

RATING: 8
I do fully acknowledge that the dice version is a "better" game. But Bang! will always be a favorite of mine. It's kind of the board game that got me back into gaming after college. I'd played it several time with my friends at Purdue, but it was when a local friend pulled out a copy that we started planning specific game nights.

Plus, there are always great jokes about banging and at least one person singing about how they didn't shoot the Deputy.

Also, I always draw Sheriff somehow, which is by far the best role to have.

RATING: 5
I played a lot of Bang! when it first came out - probably too much and I burned out on it.  In small doses, it is fun: a good but recently simple card game with lots of interaction in the form of attacking, guessing people's motives and allegiances, bluffing and some tactical card play on top of that.  It has its flaws: players can be eliminated without getting to play, games can be very long or very short and the end game can sometimes drag.  But overall, it is entertaining.

RATING: 9.5

The base game is more than enough to have tons of great games and lots of fun.

RATING: 7
The game as an idea is perfect, but the game itself with just 80 cards and 15 characters  sucks.Me and my friends have bought every expansion except Gold Rush which we will buy really soon.With every expansion the game gets better and more interesting.If you want to buy it i suggest you buy it with all the expansions in the exact order  dodge city, valley of shadows, high noon+fistful of cards,wild west show and then decide if you really want to add purchases of cards where the game gets more complicated with the addition of gold rush.The difference with each expansion is visible.Dead players can come back to life with so many ways so the thrill stays the same with the addition of new brown and blue cards.For me 7 or 8 players is the best.We never play unless we have that number.The game has become so complicated and thrilling comparing to the original bang that so many things have to be taken in mind it makes this game awesome.I higly recommend it just not by itself.At least have dodge city with you.

RATING: 6
4-7p, 30m.  The cards are really nice and sturdy with linen finish.
Only played a few times.  The first "two" were with 5 players--all new to this game (including me), and most not into games in general (except me :).  Rating may increase with more plays. First game was incredibly short due to the Sheriff getting slaughtered in a duel before we even made it once around the table.  THEN, the second game dragged on forever since I forgot the the 2nd-edition rule about the jail only lasting one turn max, so one of the outlaws spent most of the game in jail.  We all staggered away from the table in a daze, with one person muttering comments about "complex games."  I felt bad because there was so much laughter and lighthearted fun at first, but then it bogged down and became a drag.  My interest of course won't be fazed by one bad session like this since I am an enthusiast.  But I fear I soured the group.  My fault for not being more familiar with the rules.  But the game is a bit rules-heavy, and could use a good reference-sheet.
3rd play was with only 3 people, a situation in which the game is acknowledged not to shine.  This game is very social, and dependent on the group attitude.

RATING: 5
There are things I really love (the basic idea overall being the biggest), but the rules are way overly complicated and that makes it a pain to teach anyone. Add to that the totally obtuse iconography and it is sort of a mess to play if you don't know it well. Given that there is a lot of bluffing and secret identities, not knowing the rules well seriously diminishes the quality. Further, the game is best with the full number, so teaching usually happens with at least someone and it just drags the game down. 

This game is an easy 7-8 with all experienced players but can drop considerably when bogged down with people who just aren't picking up the rules.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simply put, Bang is a great filler game.  Games do not last insanely long and the action is fast paced.

The hidden player roles are what really make the game for me.  It takes a lot of strategy to successfully pull off being the deputy or the renegade well.  Putting off your primary target objective and masking your role early is vital to your victory.

My biggest complaint about the game is the sheer amount of randomness.  Characters, roles, and cards are based on the luck of the draw.  The best way that you can counter this is by trying to maximize the number of cards you draw.

Bang scales very well when playing with a larger group.  One thing I dislike the fact that it has a 4 player minimum in order to pull of the roles the game requires.  Since I do not have a regularly scheduled game night it takes a little bit of effort to put a game together.  As much as I do enjoy the game I do feel that the game's shortcomings do not make it worth putting together a game night where it is the headlining game.

RATING: 9
Played 17 times.
Last Played Mar 15, 2008

The first game we played with out the cards that required the rule book (as suggested by the rules).  It was an okay game, but then in the second game we added those cards in and boy was it so much more fun.  We had a lot of fun, and it went over with my friends even better than I had dared hope.

This game just keeps being more and more fun the more and more we play it.  It is quickly becoming a favorite among my friends.

We just played it for the first time with 4 players.  It seems that the fewer players you have the more the luck of the draw is a factor, with more players the luck is balanced out better to make for a more interesting game.

Last night we tried a new thing with the Character cards which I liked.  We dealt each player 2 cards.  They could then choose which of those two powers they wanted to use and use the other to track the life points.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Dans le port, les bateaux de commerce attendent d'être remplis de marchandises. 
Chaque navire doit stocker une certaine combinaison de marchandises. 
Les joueurs prennent le rôle de commerçants essayant de remplir leurs entrepôts de marchandises qui sont alors à leur tour transférées aux bateaux présents dans le port. 
Ils doivent prêter attention à la bonne combinaison des marchandises parce que les capitaines acceptent seulement les marchandises d'un seul commerçant et s'attendent à une livraison complète avant que leurs bateaux partent du port. 
Il est également très important de trouver le bon moment pour charger les cargaisons dans les vaisseaux car la flotte quitte le port lorsque l’espace de stockage est plein et que les vents sont favorables. 
Les joueurs doivent donc toujours anticiper les vents pour pouvoir influencer les évènements.

RATING: 5
This is an odd beast.

I have a good time pretty much every time I play.  And yet...

From the first time I played it I was never convinced it actually made sense as a game.  It seems to take far too long to explain to new players for a social game; it is too easy for a new player to misunderstand the strategy and mess up the role-guessing aspect (say by shooting the sheriff as a deputy in order not to give himself away); it is quite possible for a player to be killed before he has a chance to take any real part in the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
I really can't stand this game.  Somebody brought it in to work and we played it for about a week.  I just recently got stuck playing it at a game night at a local store.

Bang is set in the wild west, with sheriffs, deputies, outlaws, and renegades.  Each player gets two characters and chooses the one they think has the best special ability.  Then each player is dealt a role.  There will be one renegade and one sheriff, then the other players will either be outlaws or deputies.  At this point the sheriff reveals their card so everybody knows who the sheriff is, but nobody else reveals who they are.

The win condition is different for the different roles.  The sheriff and deputies win if the sheriff survives, so they are trying to kill off the renegade and the outlaws.  The outlaws just need to kill the sheriff to win.  The renegade wants to become sheriff, so this role helps everybody out at some point.  The renegade needs to kill everybody off except for the sheriff, so it comes down to a duel, then if the renegade can kill the sheriff the renegade wins.

I thought of not knowing who anybody is was kind of cool at first.  However, not having a good way to figure out who's on your team really killed this game for me.

To start out you only have a gun that has a range of one, so you can shoot the person to your left and to your right.  You can add a better gun to give you better range, get a horse to put yourself out of other peoples' range, and there are other various cards for shooting people, taking cards, making somebody miss you, beer to get health back, etc.

I give this game a 3 because it is too hard to know who is on your team.  When you do figure it out, everybody knows it, so you then have no protection.  If you start shooting at the sheriff, then the deputies are going to shoot you, then the outlaws will target the deputies, and so on.  It is a big secret until the shooting begins, then it just depends on who gets the right cards and where you are sitting.  There is just too much randomness in this game for me.

[b]Game Length:[/b] (Short) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Long)
[b]Complexity:[/b] (Easy) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Complex)
[b]Accessibility:[/b] (Non-Gamers) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Gamers)
[b]Luck Factor:[/b] (Luck Based) :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Strategy Based)
[b]Re-playability:[/b] (Low) :star::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (High)
[b]Value for Time:[/b] (Waste) :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: (Worth)
[b]Recommended # of Players:[/b] 6+
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
Best w/7, 5-7:

Relatively quick game of hidden roles and player elimination.  Best with 5 and 6 players; any fewer and there are too few roles at the table, any more and the time between turns gets excessive.  Gameplay is luck of the draw dependent.  Good for a quick warm up or light filler.

RATING: 7.25
[played 5+ times]

easy game and quite fun. Different roles doesn't have the same possibility to win (it's quite impossible in 6-7 to win as renegade), but if you don't mind you can already have fun.
It's a bit long in 6-7 players: a few games can become endless, with player waiting for the last player to die; au contraire a couple of games I played ended before the first round was completed.
I think it's better in 5 or 7 than 6: in 6 sheriff side is too weak.
Like other elimination games, who first goes out have to find something to do while waiting others finishing the game... and sometimes it can take long!

RATING: N/A
Not a bad game at all, but there are a lot of symbols on the cards that you need to know in order to play the game. The dice game version of bang solves these problems and is a better game overall.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
This card game is a fast paced game where players take hidden roles and try to kill their opponents. Chosen characters give players special abilities and a plethora of equipment, weapon and other cards add some spice and twist to the game play. The turn sequence is pretty simple; on your turn, play as many cards as you want with the exception of the Bang! cards. There is some complication with how certain cards work that first time players will need to wrap their heads around. It also doesn’t help much that the cards all have symbols on them rather than the description of what it does on the cards so expect to have the rulebook handy for MANY consultations. However, once everyone gets a good grasp and feel, which can be expected after a couple of games, then this game really shines! Beware, this game is all about conflict and trying to eliminate the other players so if that’s not your cup of tea, you may want to move on. Also, there’s lots of player interaction, as you can imagine. Add lots of negotiation and backstabbing and this game becomes a real riot!

Always a favorite with my group this is one that is in constant rotation and gets lots of play. The only real downside is player elimination, which can be a drag since some games can last a long time and players killed early can potentially find themselves sitting around. Other than that, I highly recommend this game! Great fun!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun little party game or closer, but not really a game I'd go out of my way to get. Still, might be something I could get my family to play at Christmas or something.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bang! is another in the genre of Mafia-style games, augmented with cards providing the players with various abilities. The players assume the roles of the Sheriff, some Deputies, Outlaws, and a Renegade, but only the Sheriff’s identity is known to the public. The Sheriff and Deputies must kill the Outlaws & Renegade to win, the Outlaws must kill the lawmen to win, and the Renegade only wins as the last man standing.

Players play “Bang!” cards to shoot at each other, augmenting their shots with other cards to give them further range with a rifle, for instance, or to dodge behind a barrel card for cover, or various other effects. In addition, each player is assigned a character, each with a unique ability. The game plays nicely and swiftly and is fun for a larger group.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
What's good about Bang? Party game for up to 7 players, handy when there's too many people to play good games!

The bad? You can knock out a player or two in the first two rounds, possibly before they've actually had a turn themselves! They then must sit out for what can be anywhere up to an hour or more. The instruction book and cards are also a comical mess of poor translation. Many questions will have to be guessed at to play.

The ugly? Their's no strategy whatsoever. You got a Bang? shoot the sheriff! You run out of cards? Tough you are going to die as everyone will shoot you. Then when you get down to two players its essentially down to who draws a bang and doesn't draw a miss that decides the outcome, usually the person with the most life.

For the same length of time you could play any number of much better filler games, or Cash & Guns, which has a similar theme but is much better in just about every way.

Incredibly overrated for what it is.

RATING: 7
Own both the analog version and the IOS version. I think Bang is fun but is best if played quickly, the players enjoy bluffing and mindgaming (eg "I'M not the renegade, HE is"), and the players can laugh about being eliminated by dynamite blowing up in their face. Bang rules are a bit more complicated than the average filler so it might not appeal to casual gamers. Its best with 5 players only, too, which reduces its suitability. Endgame can also drag on long after the outlaws are eliminated and its down to the deputy duking it out with the renegade with the sheriff waiting patiently to see the final identity of the second to last person standing.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
[b]Like:[/b]
-Cowboys?...

[b]Dislike:[/b]
-The game plays you, there are no decisions to be made aside from who to shoot
-Downtime

Too bad... I was interested to try this, but met with disappointment.

Player elimination, no thinking about what card to play... this is basically Uno with more rules, longer downtime and a theme slapped on.

It's too bad you need to draw 2 cards every turn (and possibly more with certain cards) cause that just leads to more downtime for all the other players.

I want to say the miss card is stupid because it just is like "I shoot you" "no you don't", but I guess that's the point this game is going for. It's just that it works better in games with a faster pace.

Okay, so the game is definitely not in the cards; it's too obvious what you need to play. So perhaps the game lies within the roles like in a game of Werewolf... the game of who to shoot.

Well, I haven't really played the game that way with lying and deduction, because the only time I was able to finish a game of this I was right next to the Sheriff and I was an Outlaw, so there was no point in shooting the unrevealed guy since that might as well be another Outlaw.

So considering that (and this is just a theory since I've only had that one experience), once everyone has gone, don't you pretty much know who to shoot? If you're a Deputy and the people next to the Sheriff shot him, you shoot them, and if none of them did your best bet is shooting all the others. If you're an Outlaw, shoot the Sheriff and if you can't hit him, shoot those who don't shoot the Sheriff or those who shoot the people who shot those that shot the Sheriff. So even deciding who to shoot isn't really a decision.

In most other hidden role games, there usually are no turn structures so everyone is involved at the same time, no waiting for your turn whatsoever. Also, you can at least say you were trying to bust other people but in this game it is just way too risky to shoot the Sheriff for that reason.

As a card game, Uno is better because it's much simpler. As a hidden role game, pretty much anything is better.

Dice game is better cause at least there you have risk management with the dynamite results.


Comment on "Owned": my brother owns this.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
I will start this comment by saying that this game would be a 10 in my opinion if every game went well.  What I mean by that is that the right people get the right cards at the right time and they play them the right way.  When this happens, even when people are out of the game, it is still a blast to cheer on the rest of the people that are playing.

However, probably every 3rd time or so, you games that literally game end within 1 round, which is no fun at all. Those would be the dud games.

Overall, I would say that this game is a blast to play and every time that we have 6 or 7 people over to play games, this is the one that I want to play.  However, you should try to play at least a couple of games because one of those games might end up being a dud.

RATING: 3
One of the character powers is a mandatory effect based on hidden information. 'nuff said.

OK, OK, full opinion. Since there's no way to determine roles, the beginning of the game is just random shooting until someone decides to antagonise the sheriff. Then the rest is mostly a lesson in imbalance, showing a poor understanding of the concepts of tempo and card advantage CCG players are familiar with; especially when you pair a defensive character with the sheriff role. Unfortunately this means that what would only be a flawed and mindless "take that" game can in many instances drag for what seems to be an eternity.

RATING: 9
I LOVE this game for its intended purpose as a party game. It is incredibly easy to teach and even non-gamers greatly enjoy it. It hits the table frequently when we have enough players, often playing it several times in a row. There are lots of great characters to choose from and the roles are splendid. The more people the more fun this game is. Easy to set-up and has high replayability. The roles may be a bit unbalanced at a 4 player game, but that's part of why it is best with more players. Fantastic party game for everyone. However, I would love to see Harry Potter version of this.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
On the surface, Bang! has a lot of qualities that could make it a worse game than it is.  It can be a fairly long game, and there is player elimination.  In fact, it is possible for a player to be eliminated before taking a turn.  Some characters are also less fun (and less powerful) than others.  As a result, Bang! can occasionally have really bad sessions that just don't work.

However, the theme and the player interaction really pull through for this one.  Most of the time its a very engaging, fun game with some great mechanics.  The hidden roles add a great deal, and the variable player powers add depth and replayability.  This is by far the most inconsistent game I own, but it is fun and supports a large group, which means it sees the table a lot.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

This game does not have a higher rating for me, because players can 
(and will) be eliminated.

RATING: 4
Perfect way to follow up a Western.  Made even better with Dodge City and the expansion cards.  A very fun game with player elimination though, but hey house rules are always there.  It's always guaranteed to produce raucous laughter among non-gamers and veteran gamers alike...

UPDATE:  The unfairness of being the renegade is bothering me quite a bit.  If you end up being it, then you're pretty much screwed.  Also, there's no much incentive to stay hidden for a long time since you don't want to waste the opportunity to play a Bang! against the person you want to kill.  Another thing is that with many players, it's quite possible by the time your turn arrives that you're in pretty bad condition and you were not able to do anything.  Player elimination is yet another problem as games might go for a while after that.  All in all, I'm liking Bang less and less...

RATING: 6.5
A nice card game to start or end a gaming night. Easy to teach and good for new players
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bang! is a very accessible game for large groups (7) where each player has a role (Sheriff, Deputy, Outlaw, or Renegade) that is kept secret. They are trying to complete the goal of their role without getting killed by the other players in the game.  The Sheriff is exposed, while the other players are secret, which means you may accidentally kill one of your teammates without intending to.  I'm usually up for this game, but the player elimination element can be tough as it leaves folks watching a game that can sometimes drag on a bit too long.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pros: Party game (7 players!), theme, theme, theme, trash talking welcome and allowed, just plain fun.  Cons: No real strategy, quirky cards/rules.

RATING: 9

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
A hidden role game where players get dealt secret cards telling them if they are a Sheriff, Deputy, Outlaw, or Renegade.  The Sheriff is the only identity that is known by the group.  Everyone takes turns 'banging' other players and by their actions people can start determining who is what role until the climax of the game where there is only one group left.

I find that with hidden role games a new player can really ruin the game if they are not a good actor or do not know the basics of how the game works.  This is one of the more simple hidden role games that usually is a hit with non-gamer friends.  There does seem to be a lot of downtime in-between player turns and if you get killed in the beginning you are eliminated with nothing to do for awhile, however, even with these drawbacks it is still a pretty enjoyable game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The rule make seance once half way though the first game. Otherwise they are hard to read to a new group. The symbols are not that clear for a new player. And some of the rule option feel they were thought while playing so are easy to understand when your underway. For a table of 6 I think removing most of the big weapons would be good.

RATING: 4
Has a lot of good points: it scales well for large numbers of players, and the hidden roles add a nice element of bluffing to a somewhat random game.  But Bang also has some significant bad elements: player elimination, often before a player gets a turn; long downtime, with nothing to do on other players' turns; too much luck ("I didn't draw a miss or a beer, so I'm dead"); too little basis for making decisions in the early game ("you're weak, so I'll shoot at you").

I don't see this as a "party" or "family" game -- I don't like games where it's possible to eliminate people and leave them with nothing to do while waiting for it to end.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Avvincente e semplice party game, è uno dei più famosi giochi di un autore italiano. La fortuna è ben bilanciata da un po' di strategia e un po' di bluff, bluf che di solito dura giusto la parte iniziale delle sfide. La principale negatività è che è facile uscire prematuramente dal gioco, a volte anche dopo pochissimo, rimanendo spettatori per il resto del gioco. La durata delle partite è imprecisata, a volte quasi interminabili rendendo il tutto frustrante per gli eliminati. Per il resto il gioco è simpatico e piacevole. Spesso vien voglia di rigiocarlo più volte di fila.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
A great game to put a large group of people in a game playing mindset. It combines the role elements of Werewolves or Mafia and the card hand strategy of games like Mille Bornes.

The only problems with this game are the unpredictable game length (can vary from 15 minutes to well over 1h in my experience) and the fact that players can be eliminated right off the start. These balancing issues can be frustrating: be sure to keep a backup game nearby (at least a playing card game) for the eliminated players to play.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
very good card game 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I have the german version of this, but I can't read german!Update- have played two games (7 player)including Dodge city. The gameplay was tedious and slow because we kept having to look up rules that should have been printed on cards, and the strategies were annoyingly shallow.I expect this would change if we to play it more, but I can't see this happening.

I don't like mechanics which encourage players to stomp on players who are already doing badly i.e. if someone has been shot at a lot, the rational thing to do is shoot at them as their hand of cards is now smaller.

Dynamite was random and didn't add much to the game- even from a thematic viewpoint as it didn't make sense- it just prety much kills off a randomly chosen player  (or they will die soon after).

Bought Dec 2006, sold to Coton Autumn 2007?

RATING: 5
It's an advanced Family Business, but adds a reason to pick on people (good) and increases the number of different cards (bad) that newbies will always be asking clarifications on. I had lots of fun with the theme and the outcomes, but it didn't make up for the lack of interesting decisions on a turn or the dead time. RATING: 9
One of the best non-traditional card games ever! Very fun theme that has been brilliantly adapted to the gameplay. Great visual design and the best card quality you can get. Due to the "hide 'n' seek" plus "backstabbing" plus team-play game mechanics this is one of the games in my collection with highest replayability, it's at its best with 5+ players.

- Rules are well structured and the game is explained easily, will appeal to virtually anyone who enjoys 15mins of great fun!

[b]Team play[/b]

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
I really don't care for this game. It is too random and at times completely unfair. Being elimiated early really sucks. I hate not knowing who are my enemies and who are my allies. And I really like Werewolf too. This is not like Werewolf because everyone knows who the sheriff is at the start of the game and there is no time set aside for discussion. Then the only way to kill someone is the random cards. Sometimes the sheriff is nearly impossible to kill depending on which character special ability he has. Your ability to target players with shot cards is based on how close they are around the table from you and what gun and horse cards players have. This sometimes causes the outcome to be determined by who is directly on the two sides of the sheriff. If they are both outlaws, sheriff dies. If they are deputies, good luck outlaws. If you are the renagade, you pretty much lose no matter what. This game just sucks. There are a lot of other little card games that are much better. If you want a western theme, try Boomtown. Better game with less random stupidness.

RATING: 8
My opinion of Bang was originally that it was seriously unbalanced and difficult, if not impossible, for the Renegade to win.  However, that was based on only player it with a large group.  After playing with a smaller group of 5 players, I found the balance to be a lot better, and the game in general to be a lot more fun.  My rating for this game rose because of this discovery.  Games that support large groups are scarce, and it's good to have them, but in the case of Bang, I'd recommend it as a 5-player game at best.

RATING: 7
[i]"I'll [b]BANG[/b] ye!"[/i]

I can see why this is so liked by players all round the world. It's fun and oozing with thematic role playing. It's simple and easy and can be taught in five minutes. Still, there was something missing (even though I really liked the game). These kinds of games should be reaaly short, like [b]Adios Amigos[/b], but I fear there's a risk that Bang! could go on forever. Also, some of the characters are really unbalanced. Sure, everything doesn't have to be equal and that's also something that comes from the RPG-department, but some are [i]REALLY[/i] [b]REALLY[/b] unbalanced.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4
This game falls under the category of Carcassonne for me: a game everyone else seems to like but I feel is completely "blah".  The gameplay is rather rote, to me, and the first couple rounds you spend discovering who is who doesn't have the same magic for me that it apparently does with everyone else.  For me, it seems to degenerate quickly from "I have no idea what to do" to "on my turn I am decidedly gonna try to shoot that guy".  No real decisions to be made and no fun besides what you may invest in it.  The beloved western theme is simply not enough to save this game for me.  (If it was, with seven people I would just as soon fire up Blazing Saddles on DVD.) Finally, the game is way too hard to explain quickly to newcomers/newbies to be a party game and too light to really call anything else.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
I had reservations getting this game, as it is mainly elimination to win, which for me is socially not a good game condition, so long as the ousted players aren't waiting too long for the next game. However, the hidden objectives and the fun the game seems to have generated overruled my concerns about elimination. Because all roles but the sheriff are secret, table talk becomes lively to determine who's who, which is a fun element. Being the sheriff also means suffering paranoia which is an interesting game situation. Alas, I should have trusted my instincts, despite the game play being interesting and fun. Now, not only is elimination an issue, but also downtime due to drawing and then playing of cards. Symbols on the card involves cross referencing(but once you get to know them play will speed up). (Also I'm finding, like the victims, with 4 players the game falls flat; you need at least 5 to introduce a deputy). I'm now considering a variant to speed up play: on your turn you either play or draw, but only draw if you have equal or less cards than life points. The other consideration is to introduce the special cards straight away as they may speed up the rate of elimination. I'm hoping these changes will salvage the game from the sale pile as I appreciate the theme and design. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Végre hozzám is eljutott ez a játék, amiről már annyi embertől hallottam ilyen-olyan kritikát. (inkább olyat, ami mellette szólt)
Kieg nélkül játszottunk az alapjátékkal. 
Hááááát. Nem volt rossz, azt nem állítom, de egy kicsit túl van értékelve. Van benne több hiba, mint pl. hogy aki kiesik az elején, az malmozhat addig, amíg véget nem ér a játék, illetve az, hogy azután, hogy kiderül hogy ki kicsoda, már nincs annyi izgalom.
Ráadásul szerintem taktikázni sem lehet benne, pláne ha már a teljes életerőn vagy.
De hogy jót is írjak róla, igazi partyjáték, jókat lehet nevetni közben.

RATING: 6
Nice western themed game where the players roles are hidden.
The gameplay based on shooting, as the game's name suggests, works fine and it plays fast.
But it has some limitations:
* it doesn't work with few players
* with beginners there are too many rules and special cards to get rapidly into it [tip: just set aside some special cards to avoid them in the first game with newbies]
* and sometimes it takes too long from the "first deaths" till the end of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.8
Needs at least 4 players to be any good at all, since distance from other players is a major feature of the game.  I liked it the first time, but upon replay, I saw its flaws more clearly.  Player elimination leaves people sitting with nothing to do while the rest of the game plays out, and as the turn goes around the table a player mostly sits there as a target with nothing to do (a bigger problem if there are more players).  Your choices are dictated to you by the very limited number of cards you draw, and almost every choice is obvious.  (He shot at me, do I play my MISSED card, or not?  Duh... I'm down a couple of hits, and drew a BEER card, do I play it or not?  Duh...)  I've decided this isn't nearly as good of a game as I thought after the first time I played it.

RATING: 6
fun game for family gatherings and for playing with non-gamer friends. i wish that the card instructions were printed on the cards in a more straight-forward manner. the way they are shorthanded with the use of symbols makes the learning curve for this game unnecessarily higher, making the first few teaching plays tedious. it's also pretty random--it is just take that card game and all the players share one single draw pile, so there's no way to insure you draw anything useful on your turn. the game can drag on on sometimes and is way too light to enjoy past 20 or so minutes of play time, so play it quickly without over thinking your turns.

RATING: 6

I find that while some games can be very tense and exciting, unfortunately others can drag on and be painful.  I don't like the fact that people can be eliminated before they even get a turn. Overall it is a game I enjoy and will continue to play it when I have the right amount of people.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5.5
In many ways, I like Bang!  I like the theme, the art on the cards is generally well done, and it facilitates a lot of fun interaction between players (a little role playing is fun!)

So....why the low rating?  There are a few things I just can't get past.  First, some players can and will get eliminated quickly.  Player elimination is always a bad idea in my opinion (even if it is thematic here).  I have seen folks killed before they get a turn in a six player game.  Sorry, that is just bad design.  If I sit down to play a game, only to get one or two turns and then get eliminated and have to wait thirty minutes doing nothing I am not happy.

Speaking of doing nothing, cards like "Jail" shouldn't be in the game.  This is essentially "Lose a Turn", another mechanic I hate.  I play games to PLAY GAMES, not to have a jail card played on me and watch everyone else play.

The Renegade role seems a really tough assignment, too.  I get why it exists - to make it more difficult to decide who is lawful and who is an outlaw.  Playing it though, kind of stinks.  Really tough for everything to align for a renegade victory.

Despite all this, BANG is still kind of fun, but it's only fun if you get to stay in the game.  I want to like it - I really do - but just too much downtime/elimination.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fast and fun game! Need 5-7 players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.7
Players: 5-7
Time: 20-45 min.

Players will be assigned to teams - Sheriff and deputies vs Outlaws - or play all for themselves as the Renegade. The Outlaws just want to kill the Sheriff. The Sheriff and deputies must kill the outlaws and renegade. The renegade must kill everyone. The twist is that all roles are confidential except for the Sheriff.

Players will have lots of different cards to play; some shoot at other players, some allow them to duck other players shots, some replenish their health, some let them put another player in jail, and many more.

RATING: 6
Bang is a decent party game, quite suitable to medium sized groups. 

The idea is pretty simple, all but one person has a hidden role. But the interactions can make for a very fun game! It is a game with player elimination, so when you have very conservative players - it can go on for a while. 

Definitely not a go-to game, it is a game I will join in if there is nothing else going on at the time.

RATING: 8
Faster and less annoying than Mafia/Werewolf. I do wish there were a little more deduction going on in games with less than 7 people -- it'd lead to more talking overall. Sometimes takes too long for what it is, especially if roles are clustered together.

With a lot of people, this one actually just drags for a really long time. I think 5 is the optimal number. With the latter size group and people who know how to play, this is an 8. With a larger group or a lot of people who don't know how to play, this drops to a 5 or a 6; Bang is not fun when it drags.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6

There is some planning in how you play a particular hand but planning ahead is virtually impossible. All in all, I highly recommend this game if you are playing with boys.

RATING: 8
Bang! ... you're dead!

I love this game. Yes, for some new comers it may be a little confusing. But once you get the hang of the cards there is no stopping you. I've played with the old and young and everyone enjoys it. 

I have taken the Distance(Gun and Horse) cards out of the game. It seems to make everything a little more simple.

Plus, try playing this game as a drinking game for some real fun. Also a great way to introduce the game with friends who are new to games. Every time get shot you drink. And every time you regain a life point you drink!

Get a little creative and make your own Bang! cards.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
This and citadels are my two favorite card games.  I love that a great number of people can play at one time.  I love how everybody's character is hidden at the beginning like that of Mafia or Werewolf (except the Sheriff of course).  I love the expansions that add more characters, guns, booze, and more.  This is a great game, and really fun to play.  The one down side is that some players might be eliminated from the game early, and then those players must passively wait and do nothing but watch.  Because of this, some of the people I like to play games with do not like this game.  but still, I highly recommend this game.  It's highly affordable, easy to carry around (small package), and a ton of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.8
fast, fun and thematic. 
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Simple and fast playing wild west -themed special power card game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fun and often frenetic! The only downside for me really is that playing time can be hard to predict. We have the third edition and prefer it to the fourth: the bullet tokens and player boards are just bloat. I like randomness and chaos and this delivers. And oh the stories this produces! In one memorable game the end dragged on for a while but the finish sure worth waiting for: After the outlaws were down the renegade and the deputy started duking it out. The sheriff didn't know which was which but finally shot down the deputy. It was just a fabulous scene to imagine: amidst lots of firing back and forth between others the sheriff finally chances it and pulls the trigger, only to take out her only friend. She falls to the ground dropping all her equipment and weeps. Helpless and cardless she waits for the renegade to finish her off, barely lifting her gaze at the barrel of his gun. Just then, that stick of dynamite that's been going around for several rounds now explodes under the renegade's feet. The sheriff wins, with nothing left of anyone else or her equipment.

Update: Cash 'n Guns has shown itself to be a strong competitor to this as they are both really party games. I'm on the lookout for a wild west shooting game that would be more tactical, more focused than Bang! At the same time, I can't forget the thrilling moments I've had with Bang!, so I'm on the fence about trading it. Would when I don't consider previous plays, won't when I do...

Traded away. A little queasy about it when I think back, there's memories attached to this game. I'd want to add something to it though, and the Bullet edition has everything. Might get this back in some years, if we dont' live near anyone that has it. Right now though, there's quite a few copies in our circle.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

Fun game that needs at least 5 people to really work.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Bang's strength is that it supports an unusally high number of players (seven), but because it's an elimination game all but two of those players will be spending a lot of time twiddling their thumbs. The endgame seems to drag a bit also, without lots of players piling on to eliminate the injured. With the right group I think it could be a lot of fun, but there are much better, non-elimination games you can play with this number (e.g. Saboteur). Or you could play Werewolf, which does the same thing at the right game length.

My strategy is to try and get eliminated first so that I can set up a two player game to play with the next person to be eliminated.

RATING: 8
This game is awesome...
...if you play fast! People who take long turns ruin this game. You don't stop and think in a game like this. After all, you would take a minute to decide your turn while standing in the middle of the town at high noon, would you?

If it's played right, it's just absolutely hilarious. You have a Sheriff placing a few rounds into his Deputy with a winchester, two Outlaws firing at each other while accusing the other of being a lowly white-hat deputy, and a Renegade trying to let everyone else destroy each other.  Just awesome for the right group.

I don't care if the Italian text adds flavor to the game. You can't make a light filler, then make it such that you have no idea what the cards do without using the rulebook (for the special cards). I like the hidden roles and picking your character in the beginning, but HATE the player elimination. Will still play just for the double entendres. Still have to try this with a large group (only tried with 4). Also must try playing in a game where I'm the only guy in it and can Bang! all I want. :devil:

RATING: 4.5
Werewolves with practically no psychology, fueled by deck of random cards. 

It's neat - the theme works, the build up is slow and comfy. Everything totally depends on the cards you get (well plus some guessing work), especially the blue cards are quite powerful. So: lots of luck, not that much bluffing, deducing, which means you're in it for the ride. Also for same reason: good for kids and people who don't know each other. 

Better than Muchkin, not as good as Cash&Guns or Citadels. A neat ride when you want it. 

EDIT: Iconitis sucks for such a light game. 
EDIT: dice game dice game dice game

RATING: 7
Combining elements of Werewolf and Miles Borne, Bang! is a great party hit. There are not too many cards to learn so that new people can jump right in. I love the unknown role factor and the idea that where you sit at the table makes a difference.
The only issue the game has is that someone could get killed quite early and thus be out of the action.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Given the amount of plays this could be considered my #1 party game. Personally, I do not like the game that much, it has too many drawbacks for my liking (player elimination, highly luck driven, with some people it even gets very annoying). But it is enjoyed by many people I game with and it is an easy choice for a relaxing game with 5-7 people to play.
I would not recommend to play the game with someone who likes to think a lot. This is not a thinking game. Or just quickly shoot him.

RATING: 4
Maybe it's the people that I've played this with, but the deduction/bluffing didn't play nearly as big of a role as I thought it would.  

At its core, its a hand-management beer-and-pretzels player elimination game where it doesn't ever feel like progress is made.  More often than not, I've seen games decided by the Dynamite card, which makes me feel like I could have just played a round of Russian Roulette and saved the overhead of the game.

I've only played it a handful of times, and I already feel like I'm just going through the motions of playing it.

RATING: 5
Can be fun with a large group. The hidden roles, team-based gameplay, and the wild west theme go a long way. Player elimination is an issue, and the game can go on a lot longer than it should, but there's nothing more satisfying than being in (and winning) the final duel. Distill that into a game and I'd be elated. Like Citadels, with the right group, in the right mood, Bang! works wonderfully. Beer and a group of good friends who don't mind filling time with conversation. That's the key.  In the wrong context, with the wrong group, it can be painful.

RATING: 4

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
This is one of my favorite hidden role games because there's so much interaction with the other players.  Games like The Resistance don't do anything for me because you don't interact with the other players besides the normal mind and word games to figure out who they are.  Bang! still has all that and so much more.  You can still interrogate and try to get the other players to slip up and reveal who they are while at the same time playing a Western-themed card game.  I've played it so much I've lost a little love for it, but it is still an incredibly well-designed, fun, and exciting game and one of the best games with hidden role mechanics that I've played.  I will concede it can be really crappy when the odds are against a player and they find themselves eliminated quickly and watching the game finish from the sidelines though.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
I have played this game many times and it has always been enjoyable. I used to play with a group of 5 friends and at one point this game was one of the only games that we could all agree on to play. That being said, I have not played it since the dice version of the game cam out. Although I don't own the dice version, I have been contemplating getting it for quit a while and will probably own it in the near future. The dice game and the card game hold numerous similarities in how they play but the dice version takes considerably less time and for a social interaction and deception game, that it makes the dice version a much better choice in my opinion.
I wont forget you BANG!...but I don't think I'll play you again.

RATING: 7
Great fun, easy to teach and pick up the rules. This game is all about bluffing. The mechanics and strategy are pretty simple, but where the real magic happens is the deception, redirection, and psychological mind-bending as everyone tries to fool each other and play all the other sides against each other (not to mention your choice of cheesy Italian or cheesy Western accents while playing). "Not me, Sheriff, I'm legit!" out one side of your mouth, "No way, pardner, I don't truck with the law!" out the other.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
[daVinci games 03 edition] {American West; variable-player-powers, partnership, player elimination, deduction, variable-winning-goal; optimal 6p} Bang! is an interesting thematic role-play game. It is full of player interactions and gossips. It is more suitable for aggressive plays; if most players try their best to avoid confrontation / hide their identity, the game dies. It's fun; esp. for families and general players; hardcore gamers decide / plan too much and destroy the flow of the game! It allows certain kinds of strategies; esp. for the Renegade.

The rules are long but not complex. It takes less time to teach the rules but the players may need some time to get used to the cards. The FAQ is quite helpful to handle special situations.

[Update] The Deluxe version is really attractive.  Unless I can trade away Bang! and Dodge City, I would not get it.

[Expansions] High Moon is good to have, but not necessary. Dodge City is a nicer choice. Fist of handful cards is not necessary unless you think the Sheriff is too weak.

RATING: N/A
Quando l’uomo col Winchester incontra l’uomo con la pistola, l’uomo con la pistola è un uomo morto... a meno che non abbia una Volcanic!

I Fuorilegge danno la caccia allo Sceriffo. Lo Sceriffo dà la caccia ai Fuorilegge. Il Rinnegato trama nell’ombra, pronto a schierarsi da una parte o dall’altra. Le pallottole volano.
Chi fra i pistoleri sarà un aiutante dello Sceriffo, pronto a sacrificarsi per lui?
E chi invece uno spietato Fuorilegge, che non aspetta altro che farlo fuori?
Il gioco western più venduto del mondo, oggi in una versione ancora più ricca e facile da imparare!

Contenuto:

7 ruoli (1 Sceriffo, 2 Vice, 3 Fuorilegge, 1 Rinnegato)
16 personaggi
80 carte da gioco
7 carte riassuntive
7 plance personali
30 segnalini pallottola
1 libretto delle regole a colori

RATING: 8
Great game for a bigger group!  Lots of fun and lots of theme.  Also like that you can play games pretty quick so you can play it a few times.  It is an elimination game however, sometimes players who get killed early end up waiting a while for the next game to start.  Also, new players have a hard time the first game or two learning all the card meanings.  You must play this several times to really appreciate it, although I had fun the very first time.  Good idea to play without the 12 "advanced" cards when playing with new players.

RATING: 4.75

The fact there is Player Elimination and tons of imbalances and randomness and more is just not my cup of tea anymore. I'd rate it a 5 or a 5.25, but the components are pretty bad and the dual language and heavy use of iconography knocks it down to a much lower rating. Not something I'd really play unless there was no other social deduction game option.

RATING: 9
Bang! is Mafia with a western twist and a very engaging style of play. It's a game of deception (and also power in the case of the Sheriff) and it's very satisfying when you start figuring out the others' roles while concealing your own. The point in which you openly reveal what role you have is very important. The only setback this game has is when there are players that either do not know how to play their roles correctly or when you have players that reveal who they are from the get-go (either accidentally or intentionally).

RATING: 3
It was sort of an interesting novelty at first but after several plays I now refuse to play this as the game length, as well as down time between turns is horrible. the last time we played, I think we had 7 players and it took 3 hours. WHich is too much for me for any game unless it was some epic strategic game. 

The slow down time between turns also really kills the theme of a wild west gunfight. It is more about figuring out who is on what side than anything to do with shooting people. This also starts to kill the excitement as the most strategy revolves around the mystery roles, and after an hour or so you begin to have an idea, but it will still take many turns before you can finish off certain players. The latter stages of the game more resemble a siege than anything else.

RATING: 7.5
Bang!  YEHAW!  This here cardgame is an absolute blast!  Ain't no tumbleweeds in this here town.  The game is oozing with spagetti western theme.  Mechanics are easy to teach and pictorial (except a select few cards with the book icon).  Really easy to understand as well, minimal learning curve.  Brilliant little game about bluffing with a quick pace, the shots just keep coming.  Heavy roleplaying element with the right group of players and laughs all the way through.  The player elimination is unfortunate but still doesn't retract too much from the game.  Amazing party game, the more players the more fun!  I really enjoy a good bang from time to time.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
