RATING: 7.5
It's fun, but honestly?  I'd rather player Werewolf.  Bang!, though, is nice at lower player counts where Werewolf often fails.

Revised September 2009 from 5 to 7 - played it with a new group of people and it was a hit.  It always fell flat before, but with a new group it took off and it's been oft-requested.  I took out the most complicated cards for the first play and explained the basics, and that got everyone involved.  Some games you just need the right group!  I'm even considering getting the Bullet to offer greater versatility in play.

Revised July 2012 from a 7 to 7.5 - a minor upgrade but I picked up the version in the larger box that actually changes the cards so that you don't have to go to the manual to see what so many of them do.  This is a HUGE help in introducing the game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Bang is my go-to game for killing time with my sports team.  They seem to love it, so I keep it around.  

I do see the negative qualities though.  In particular, I'm often the first one eliminated.  It usually happens when I've just explained the game, and no one wants to target someone who doesn't know how to play, so instead they shoot at me.  
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Was enjoyable for a while, but now it's monotonous.  A player's hand will play itself, and there is no real strategy or tactics to speak of.  Some cards are really useless.  Figuring out range is a headache when there are blue cards and character cards that change the distance.  I'm also sick and tired of being asked what different cards do.  Hidden role mechanic seems like an afterthought, not as integral to the experience as in, say, Saboteur or Werewolf.

The game is almost always decided by dynamite.

RATING: 7
The hidden roles are a myth.  After one round, pretty much everyone knows who everyone else is.  The most interesting games are the ones where for some reason people get confused.  Unfortunately, that pretty much always means the sheriff wins.  All that said, I still have fun playing this if there are enough players.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.2
I've come to enjoy "secret role" type games a lot recently, having played Saboteur, Saboteur 2 and The Resistance. So I was hoping this would play something like Resistance, but with the addition of some extra stuff to do each turn, and a dash of comedy chaos. In theory, that's exactly what this game is, but somehow the sum of the parts adds up to much less than the whole. The secret role aspects don't work anywhere near as well as Resistance, or even Saboteur, leaving you either totally in the dark over who to attack, or making it painfully obvious. The shooting mechanic quickly gets tiresome too. It's a shame, as I thought this would be a lot of fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
For all of the complexity baked into the cards, bullets, and now player mats, Bang! is really a simple card game that relies heavily on social interaction.  If the group that you're playing with has a lot of personality, the game will flourish.  The Dodge City! expansion is nearly required.

RATING: N/A
A rough and tumble gunfightin' card game that really brings out the cowboys in everyone. Play with a cheatsheet, as some cards lack important rules text. Works great with larger numbers and fast play, though the game can occasionally drag due to a slow player or a random shuffle (especially in expansion games). Tip -- Discard health cards permanently when used. This will guarantee the game will come to a speedy end.

RATING: 6

Rules used:
Play with Expansion Characters, but only the Basic cards.

RATING: 5
It's alright.  I like Bang! but want to enjoy it more than I do. It's hard to enthusiastically endorse a game in which you can be gunned down before you even have a turn.  It would also be nice if the hidden role mechanism mattered a little more.  When it's on, it's on, though, and I love the player powers and overall presentation.  Generally I'd reach for Cash n Guns if I wanted a firearms-themed party game, but I'll still break this out when I can.

RATING: 7

M. is shooting at B. with a volcanic.

M:  Bang!

B:  Missed.

M:  Bang!

B:  Missed.

M (ever more desperate):  *Bang!*

B:  That's a *beer*.

RATING: 5.5
Fun, interactive game of "take that" with a dash of deduction thrown into the mix.  Not too much to think about here, and the player elimination can leave some players twiddling their thumbs, but it's still a fine diversion every once in a while.  Definitely gets bonus points for handling up to seven players.

UPDATE: With more experience with other, better games, Bang's flaws have been harder to overlook.  Or maybe it fits a niche that I'm not really interested in.  This doesn't get to the table anymore and I can't imagine it ever being played except by my high school students - and even then I'd rather sit out.

RATING: 8

A great gateway game to get your "too cool for school friends" into boardgames.

RATING: 6
This game banged the group I first tried it with and we played it 8 times in a row... I rarely see a game arouse so much interest.. 

It's a highly interactive gunsling "simulation" game, with some interesting light deduction elements. It does create a good narrative, it is dripping in theme and flows well.

However it is too random and chaotic for my taste, and not too elegant. Some games may end quickly enough, but some may drag insanely long. Combine this with player elimination and you get a game that may force someone to watch instead of play..

It generally is a fun game, with the right crowd.

RATING: 5
This is a pure fun-factor game, and is obviously not going to make anyone General Patton by the choices they make.

I've cooled a bit on Bang! lately... It seems like you run out of cards way too fast, and your options become very limited as the game continues on.  I've seen a couiple of matches drag out to almost an hour, which seems insane for a game of this simplicity.

As other users have said on BGG, there is better filler around.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I'm pretty late to the bandwagon on this one, but I finally got around to playing it.  

And... it's not horrible?  But to be honest I'm not even that convinced that it's not.  It's a player elimination game where you can get knocked out early and wait around a long time.  And it's all card dependent, which mostly means you're at the luck of the draw.  The one real game element are the hidden roles and trying to figure out who is who and work with your team or pretend to be on the other team.

It was a fun quick play when I played it.  But if I had gotten knocked out and/or the game had dragged on, it would have gotten old fast.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 5
my first thoughts:
perfect light game, my family would love it. 

nextL i am starting to sour on it, after just a few plays...but mostly because the expansions make it too long and random.

now: pretty much never need to play again. Certain parts of the game make no sense...there is no incentive to keep the roles secret, because either the outlaws attack the sheriff and out themselves, or they attack randomly and just hurt each other. If the outlaws don't out themselves, the deputies are forced to play random. There is no drive for any other play. This and the good cards (guns, horses) make too big a difference and are so random. Also, a game for nongamers? then why do I need to explain Distance to Shoot over and over again?

RATING: 5
A decent stab at a semi-diplomatic, quick card playing game with "Take that!" elements, with a modicum of strategy, that goes on a bit too long.  You need just the right set of brisk and aware players for this to come alive.

For a quick "Take that!" style game, I'd rather play Family Business.  For somewhat the same strategy and feel, I'd rather play Ca$h and Guns, which is quicker, more light-hearted, and has a higher "fun factor".

RATING: 5
Seems like a great idea for a quick little game.  But it drags, and drags, and drags, and people seem to come back from the brink of death way too often.  Almost a very good game, but is rather one of the many games intended to hit the "quick, light" sweet spot that just goes on too long.  In the same time you could play China, or Samurai, or St. Petersburg.  One nice mechanic - using the back of two cards to show remaining life.  See my review.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9
I can't help it that I love this game. It is one of my favorites. The main downside is it's best with 7-8 players and I seldom find so many with as much enthusiasm for it as I have (It is not the same playing even the best of games with those who don't get it or just don't care). The game itself is easy to learn and likely to appeal to a wide audience. The renegade is perhaps the funnest role for the bluffing factor (although generally difficult). Also there is an element of player elimination (but this seems minimized with the Wild West expansion in which dead characters can return, or roles can be switched).

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I only bought this game after I played it three times because it is so cheap and, as card games go, quite original (with a strong theme). So far (playing with 5 or 6 players), I did not enjoy playing the game too much. There is A LOT of randomness in there, and during my last session a player was actually removed from the game before he had the chance to play any cards himself. This was possible due to some "ganging up" and the starting hand dealt to each player.
UPDATE: Somehow, I played this game a lot more after this initial review and it really does grow on you! No choice but to raise the mark to a 7, for it is quite a reasonable party game.
UPDATE 2: Played this game again after a couple of years with players who are both familiar with it and like(d) it. After 2,5 hours of play (with 6 players) we stopped. It had been an agonizing experience. At least by todays standards the game has not been designed very well. Dropped rating to reflect how I feel about it now.

04/2008:5
Good game with larger crowds, but no more than 5. With 6, the downtime can be high. RATING: 6
Bang! is an awesome card game with shoot-em-up and mafia elements, though I always find that at least one person gets completely screwed over when I introduce it to a new group. Requires a couple of plays for everyone to get a handle on it.

Edit: After diming this sucker, it's become abundantly clear that 7-8 players is a real slog. There's just too much downtime, and add in newbs or AP prone people and you've got a recipe for a dull grind. It's fun, but better with less.

RATING: 7

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
In a sense, Bang! is the thinking man's Munchkin. You have a clear objective, but you don't know who your enemies are, and that makes for an interesting game.

Unlike Munchkin, this game doesn't punish players for wiping out the opposition. It is still luck-based, but when you're playing it, you feel like you have more control.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Pros: random roleplaying, theme implemented well, party game for larger groups (can be played successfully with 8+ players), moderate strategic bluffing

Cons: player elimination, limited strategy, can overstay its welcome at times, looks like a social deduction game but doesn't really scratch that itch properly

One of the better party games out there, mainly because it does not feel like a stereotypical luck-driven party game. More decision-making than the average party game plus role-playing & intrigue is cause for a grand ol' time. A major downside of the game though is that the mystery of "who's who" rarely lasts more than a few turns, as there is no reason for the outlaws to delay attacking the sheriff, and from there it is easy to deduce everyone else's role.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 3
This reminds me of the dozens of terrible party games put out by Hasbro on a yearly basis, only worse.  Disappointingly imbalanced.  Too long.  No strategy.  Too difficult to explain all the symbols to newbies, and not entertaining enough to bring out often enough to get familiar enough with the rules.  This game needs a full blown English edition, with the text on the cards.  It's difficult to understand what the card symbols mean, and the player aid cards don't really help.  This game is a study in bad design.  Why does this filler need EXACTLY seven players to work best?  That's a group size I almost never have around.  What, are we supposed to play it between games of [gameid=483] or something?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Pretty fun party game. However, the hidden roles are actually a little bit stupid. Shooting the sheriff pretty much immediately identifies you as an outlaw, and usually if you are an outlaw within range of the sheriff it is correct to immediately start shooting him. This means that sometimes the "hidden" roles are literally revealed in the first round of play, although there is always some ambiguity over which player is the Renegade and which player is the Deputy.

Another problem is that the Renegade never ever freaking wins, which can be frustrating if you're given his card over and over on a particular night.

Still, the flavor of the game is spot on, the special character abilities are great (albeit hilariously imba), and the game can get very tense if the battle is fair. Overall this is a game I'd never turn down, in spite of its problems.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6.5
Fast paced antagonistic card game where the players assume hidden roles and win or loose as a team (sherrif and helpers, bandits and the renegade who plays on his own). The interesting bit is that not only do you not know the other players' roles but even after you figure them out you cannot necessarily strike them if you don't own the proper guns. With the proper crowd can be really good fun. Suffers from early player elimination problems and needs at least 5 people to play properly.

RATING: 6

Fairly quick game,  but even so, feels a touch long.  It's all about "Take That!"  mechanisms here, so be forewarned.

Really, there are way too many special cases - what's the point of icons when almost every card has a different one?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Suitable social game. As an interesting note, I've 4 times played the sheriff in this game, and all 4 times I killed everyone at the table, including my own deputies. I mean that, every single killing shot came from me that put a person out of the game. It's not supposed to be done that way guys, you're supposed to keep your deputies alive! Ooooops. There's a lot of silly banter for this game, from the usual 'I shot the sheriff', and 'I didn't kill the deputy' to 'I fought the law and the law won', not to mention of course other spin offs of songs and little puns. No game of Bang! can escape them.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
android

RATING: 6
My chief complaint with this game is with people who over analyze things and take forever to take their turns.  For me this is a quick shoot em' up western game, that creates situations based on who is who (like werewolves of miller's hallow for example).  While there certainly is a strategy in playing cards, due to the random nature of what you draw, strategy doesn't play as much of a role as luck.  So that being said if I'm playing with folks that understand that, and make the most of the roles and characters its a pretty fun game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: N/A
This card game recreates an old-fashioned spaghetti shoot-out, with each player randomly receiving a Character card to determine special abilities, and a secret Role card to determine their goal. The Outlaws hunt the Sheriff. The Sheriff hunts the Outlaws. The Renegade plots secretly, ready to take one side or the other.

A player's Role is kept secret, except for the Sheriff. BANG! cards let you shoot at another player assuming the target is within "range" of your current gun.

RATING: 9
A brilliant little card game, mixing luck, skill and good sense.  Great for people who don't play Eurogames all that often, it's quick and easy to learn and people *always* want another go!

Under my three standard categories:
Complexity scores about 1.5 out of 5; for reference, this puts it between TransAmerica and Settlers.
Choice scores 2 out of 5; there is a lot of chance in the draw of the cards.  However, there is skill needed, too.
Conversation hits the high 5; this game is all about the opposition and really encourages the players to interact.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Simple game that is perfect for casual game nights with friends. Best with maximum number of players: the more you are the best time you'll have believe me! There's a little social deduction aspect to the game that I really enjoy. The only problem of this game, in my opinion, is that if you die early on, you are done! You are out of the game until the very end...

RATING: 4
This game went over well with our group. Played twice with 5 players. My only complaint is that it was pretty obvious what role each player was.

Will play with 7 on Christmas, and I'm hoping for the deduction element to show itself. Having said that, I'm worried that the game will drag.

The theme is great, however, and that's a plus for me.

UPDATE: Played with 7. It was a lot of fun. only deputy ended up killing another deputy. My one and only complaint with the game is that is it hard to teach. It's amazing how complicated the cards are for a simple, party game.

UPDATE: Dropping the rating from a 8 to a 6. So much of this game depends on seating arrangement and special powers. In the 6-7 player games, someone will undoubtedly be eliminated within the first 2-3 rounds. While I would never hate a game because of luck elements, there does seem to be a fair amount of predetermination after the roles are passed out. Oh well. Everyone always has a good time. 

UPDATE: Going down to a 5 because Bang! The Dice Game is so much better. Don't buy this game! Buy the dice version!

RATING: 6.5
Easy to learn, fun to play. Fast and furious action, where folks really get into shouting out BANG! every time they take a pot shot. A party game masquerading as a card game. My opinion is dropping quickly, though, based on some insanely long games where players perform seemingly random moves with no thought to the goals, or take exceedingly long amounts of time to play a card or two. This game should have a brisk pace and play in 30 minutes or so, otherwise, it's far too long and far too repetitive.

RATING: 6
Super dependent on who you're playing with and how many people are playing.  I also feel like the beginning of the game has no real strategy; you can tell everyone you're good or bad till you're blue in the face, but inevitably it comes down to people randomly shooting at each other and not having much of a strategy until the end.  Also, the game can last a long time once people have been kicked out leaving players just waiting for it to end.  This happened to me as I was killed the first round when teaching the game because "I had an advantage playing the game" and had to wait and explain the game for 45 minutes until it ended.
